Color, detail and narrative flow are all nicely handled in this life of the discoverer of the optics of color, the laws of motion, universal gravitation and the calculus -- a man whose life has resisted scrutiny because he was reclusive by nature and evaded criticism by going incommunicado.
JARHEAD: A Marine's Chronicle of the Gulf War and Other Battles. By Anthony Swofford. (Scribner, $24.) A hair-raising memoir that captures the hilarity, tedium and loneliness of the prewar deployment, followed by the appalling, astonishing experience of combat itself, in which terror and joy were one.
JOHN PAUL JONES: Sailor, Hero, Father of the American Navy. By Evan Thomas. (Simon & Schuster, $26.95.) A fascinating life of the reckless adventurer whose mad-dog pugnacity during the Revolution won fights at sea that a sane man would have bent on all sail to avoid.
JOURNAL OF THE DEAD: A Story of Friendship and Murder in the New Mexico Desert. By Jason Kersten. (HarperCollins, $24.95.) A spare, understated account of two inexperienced young men from around Boston who camped out in the New Mexico desert with three pints of water between them and got lost.
KRAKATOA. The Day the World Exploded: August 27, 1883. By Simon Winchester. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) A brilliantly rendered narrative of one of the biggest volcanic explosions in recorded history; Winchester, trained as a geologist, identifies the massive forces at work and tallies the 36,000 deaths, caused not by lava and noxious gases but by seismic sea waves.
THE LANGUAGE POLICE: How Pressure Groups Restrict What Students Learn. By Diane Ravitch. (Knopf, $24.) Education is so squeezed by "bias and sensitivity panels," Ravitch argues in this persuasive study, that what started as an admirable attempt to balance instruction has evolved into censorship.
THE LAST GOOD SEASON: Brooklyn, the Dodgers, and Their Final Pennant Race Together. By Michael Shapiro. (Doubleday, $24.95.) An engaging chronicle of the Dodgers' 1956 season, their next-to-last in Brooklyn, and a sympathetic defense of the team's owner, Walter O'Malley, whose unsuccessful quest for a new stadium ended with the team's departure for Los Angeles.
LAST MAN OUT: The Story of the Springhill Mine Disaster. By Melissa Fay Greene. (Harcourt, $25.) Greene's subject is a coal-mining accident that took place in October 1958 beneath Springhill, Nova Scotia. Nineteen men survived in pockets, to be rescued by fellow workers; Greene notes that television made the event the first mass-consumption disaster.
A LIFE OF PRIVILEGE, MOSTLY. By Gardner Botsford. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) Botsford's lively memoir of growing up as a New Yorker covers his experiences in World War II, but revolves mainly around his years at The New Yorker and the magazine's turbulent internal power struggles.
LOST IN AMERICA: A Journey With My Father. By Sherwin B. Nuland. (Knopf, $24.) Nuland, a distinguished surgeon and medical writer, counts the cost of success in this memoir about becoming an assimilated second-generation American from a home dominated by his angry, altogether unassimilable Orthodox Jewish father.
LOST PROPHET: The Life and Times of Bayard Rustin. By John D'Emilio. (Free Press, $35.) A historian's life of the gay black man he perceives as the "master strategist of social change," who organized the March on Washington for civil rights in 1963 and formulated procedures for Martin Luther King.
LOVE AND HATE IN JAMESTOWN: John Smith, Pocahontas, and the Heart of a New Nation. By David A. Price. (Knopf, $25.95.) A solid, absorbing history of Jamestown (founded 1607), the first English-speaking colony in North America to survive. Its hero is John Smith, but not the same old John Smith; this one is a student of Machiavelli and soldier of fortune who was just what Jamestown needed, especially to deal with the Indians.
MADAM SECRETARY. By Madeleine Albright. (Miramax, $27.95.) A memoir unlike any other by a secretary of state, focusing as much on Albright's voyage of personal discovery -- and the tension between insecurity and ambition -- as on the history of foreign policy during the Clinton administration.
THE MAIN ENEMY: The Inside Story of the CIA's Final Showdown with the KGB. By Milt Bearden and James Risen. (Random House, $27.95.) A trove of stories on once deeply classified subjects in the C.I.A./K.G.B. "mole wars" of the 1980's. Bearden, a 30-year C.I.A. veteran, and Risen, a reporter for The Times, toggle between the thoughts of C.I.A. spymasters and their K.G.B. counterparts, revealing the tricks each side used to throw the other off balance.
THE MEANING OF EVERYTHING: The Story of the Oxford English Dictionary. By Simon Winchester. (Oxford University, $25.) The real story is mostly the story of James Murray, a schoolteacher who knew everything (as so many Victorians did) and who edited the great dictionary heroically from 1879 to 1915 (others completed its 15,490 pages in 1928).
MERCHANTS OF IMMORTALITY: Chasing the Dream of Human Life Extension. By Stephen S. Hall. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) A lucid, thorough report on the developments in biology -- cloning, stem cells, "longevity genes" -- that may not bring about immortality but appear to carry hope of making life a little longer and a great deal nicer toward the end.
MIDDLETOWN, AMERICA: One Town's Passage From Trauma to Hope. By Gail Sheehy. (Random House, $25.95.) In Middletown, N.J., which lost nearly 50 people on Sept. 11, Sheehy intensively observed many survivors and found a positive message: this huge bereavement is also a passage, from which people emerge much changed but alive and effectual.
THE MISS STONE AFFAIR: America's First Modern Hostage Crisis. By Teresa Carpenter. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) A meticulous account of the six-month odyssey that began when some Macedonian Bulgarian revolutionaries kidnapped an American missionary spinster and a pregnant Bulgarian woman in 1901.
MR. JEFFERSON'S UNIVERSITY. By Garry Wills. (National Geographic, $20.) A short, scholarly, insightful rendering of the forms and ideas of Jefferson and his project, a rotunda and double row of pavilions that have more than once been cited as America's greatest work of architecture; Wills's great strength lies in his ability to see political and social ideas in their architectural expressions.
MONEYBALL: The Art of Winning an Unfair Game. By Michael Lewis. (Norton, $24.95.) Lewis, the author of "Liar's Poker," examines the proceedings of Billy Beane, general manager of the Oakland Athletics, who finished first in the American League West last year with as many victories as the Yankees despite the third-smallest payroll in the major leagues.
MONSTER OF GOD: The Man-Eating Predator in the Jungles of History and the Mind. By David Quammen. (Norton, $26.95.) A fine science writer's account of efforts to preserve large carnivores like tigers and crocodiles, and a meditation on what life would be like without them.
MOUNTAINS BEYOND MOUNTAINS. By Tracy Kidder. (Random House, $25.95.) A completely absorbing portrait of Paul Farmer (MacArthur "genius" grant, 1993), a driven, dedicated, rigidly idealistic doctor who commutes between Harvard and Haiti, where he works like mad to relieve the suffering of some of the poorest people on earth.
MOUNTAINS OF THE MIND. By Robert Macfarlane. (Pantheon, $24.) What compels mountain climbers to risk themselves isn't so much their free spirit as the power of advertising; Macfarlane, an English journalist, traces three centuries of thinking that rationalized and romanticized the landscape.
NELSON: Love & Fame. By Edgar Vincent. (Yale University, $35.) This deeply historical, psychological and technical examination of Britain's seaborne superstar of the Napoleonic Wars amply shows how little prepared he was to meet Emma Hamilton; his vulnerability on land was as spectacular as his competence at sea.
THE OPPOSITE OF FATE: A Book of Musings. By Amy Tan. (Putnam, $24.95.) In this collection of sharp autobiographical essays, Tan reports on her own very American negotiations with her Chinese background and destiny, including a peaceful settlement with a depressive mother, hellbent on raising an obedient daughter.
OUR OWN DEVICES: The Past and Future of Body Technology. By Edward Tenner. (Knopf, $26.) Charming, loosely connected essays on developments like eyeglasses, shoes, chairs and other inventions that have changed our lives and bodies in unforeseen ways (tender feet, weaker spines); by a researcher at the National Museum of American History.
PARTING THE DESERT: The Creation of the Suez Canal. By Zachary Karabell. (Knopf, $27.50.) An authoritative account of the work of Ferdinand de Lesseps, a Frenchman who replaced sand with seawater in 1869, allowing great ships and Western prestige to fare expeditiously through the middle of the Muslim heartland.
PERSEPOLIS. By Marjane Satrapi. (Pantheon, $17.95.) A dramatic, witty, insouciant autobiography in bold, densely rendered comic-book form by a woman born to the leftish secular bourgeoisie of 1960's Iran; she was 10 when the shah fell and his tyranny was replaced by the ayatollah version. The book ends when she is 14 and her parents put her on a plane for some safer place (she now lives in France).
PIECES OF MY MIND: Essays and Criticism 1958-2002. By Frank Kermode. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) A collection that condenses a lifetime of careful reading and intense critical activity into 26 essays addressing in disarmingly straightforward prose the big questions of half a century: What is modernity? What is a classic? What is criticism for?
POSITIVELY FIFTH STREET: Murderers, Cheetahs, and Binion's World Series of Poker. By James McManus. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Assigned to cover the event for Harper's Magazine, McManus entered the tournament and finished fifth, winning a fair bundle and a useful point of view not often accessible to the literati.
A POTENT SPELL: Mother Love and the Power of Fear. By Janna Malamud Smith. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) A fervent examination of the powerful, visceral anxiety of mothers for their children's lives and welfare, and of its exploitation by experts and authorities interested in keeping mothers scared and in their place.
PROTECTING AMERICA'S HEALTH: The FDA, Business, and One Hundred Years of Regulation. By Philip J. Hilts. (Knopf, $26.95.) A thoroughly documented history of the first internal federal agency charged with protecting individual citizens, and of numerous efforts to improve it or wreck it since its beginnings.
PUBLIC PLACES: My Life in the Theater, With Peter O'Toole and Beyond. By Sian Phillips. (Faber & Faber, $30.) A finely observed memoir, by a versatile actress, that recalls a marriage in the limelight and considers the plight of smart women chained to impossible men.
PUSHKIN: A Biography. By T. J. Binyon. (Knopf, $35.) An informed study by a lecturer in Russian literature at Oxford, presenting a man tormented by irrational fits, mood swings, delusional jealousy, huge debts and general disorganization, with few redeeming factors besides his genius as a poet.
RAISING AMERICA: Experts, Parents, and a Century of Advice About Children. By Ann Hulbert. (Knopf, $27.50.) To what, exactly, has the vast body of expert opinion about child rearing finally amounted? Hulbert's prodigious collection of material represents it mainly as teeter-tottering between discipline and permissiveness, sometimes inside the same expert at different stages.
REEFER MADNESS: Sex, Drugs, and Cheap Labor in the American Black Market. By Eric Schlosser. (Houghton Mifflin, $23.) Schlosser, the author of "Fast Food Nation," turns his attention to three facets of America's estimated $650 billion underground economy, blending big-picture analyses with fascinating individual case studies.
REGARDING THE PAIN OF OTHERS. By Susan Sontag. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.) In this long, reflective essay, which examines photographs of calamities and the moral uses of looking at them, Sontag follows the trail of photojournalism from the Crimean War on and refines some of the observations of her 1977 book, "On Photography."
RETURN TO PARIS: A Memoir. By Colette Rossant. (Atria, $22.) For Rossant, a cookbook author, coming-of-age in Paris meant being torn between two homes (Egypt and France) and, inevitably, two culinary cultures.
RIVER OF SHADOWS: Eadweard Muybridge and the Technological Wild West. By Rebecca Solnit. (Viking, $25.95.) A remarkable historical reading of the American West as a fount of technological and perceptual change, arising from a study of Muybridge, whose stop-motion photos presaged the movies.
THE ROAD TO HOME: My Life and Times. By Vartan Gregorian. (Simon & Schuster, $29.95.) Born to a poor family of Christian Armenians in Iran, Gregorian rose to become president of the New York Public Library and, later, the president of Brown University, but maintains the capacity for astonishment in this graceful memoir.
ROSEMARY AND BITTER ORANGES: Growing Up in a Tuscan Kitchen. By Patrizia Chen. (Scribner, $24.) A dreamy memoir of her childhood in postwar Livorno; Chen remembers her grandparents fondly, but where food is concerned, she disavows their culinary blandness and allies herself with the family's adventurous cook.
SEA OF GLORY: America's Voyage of Discovery, the U.S. Exploring Expedition, 1838-1842. By Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $27.95.) A fascinating, meticulous account of an immense (six ships, 346 men) project whose prime purpose was to produce charts for American whalers; the last all-sail mission to circumnavigate the globe, it logged 87,000 miles in four years but lost recognition when Americans took to expanding westward on the ground.
SECRET EMPIRE: Eisenhower, the CIA and the Hidden Story of America's Space Espionage. By Philip Taubman. (Simon & Schuster, $27.) Taubman, a longtime correspondent and editor for The Times, chronicles the development of overhead reconnaissance, a technology that made the world safer by providing accurate information about Soviet capacities.
SEEKING RAPTURE: Scenes From a Woman's Life. By Kathryn Harrison. (Random House, $22.95.) Personal essays by a novelist whose characters have been shadowed by possession; here she inspects the turbulence of her own past, examining love and its distortions in a family -- notably her worship of her mother and her drastic efforts to cure it.
THE SERENITY PRAYER: Faith and Politics in Times of Peace and War. By Elisabeth Sifton. (Norton, $26.95.) A loving portrait, by a distinguished book editor, of her father, the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr (possibly the author of the famous prayer), and the friends and family, mainly social and religious progressives, who once spent their summers in an idyllic nowhere in northwestern Massachusetts, a village whose sweetness Sifton renders palpable.
SEVEN AGES OF PARIS. By Alistair Horne. (Knopf, $35.) A British historian's evocation of the world's favorite city, from its Roman period to the riots of 1968. His heroes are the builders who made Paris: Louis IX with his Sainte-Chapelle, Henri IV for his Place des Vosges, Baron Haussmann for the open, harmonious plan that marks Paris to this day.
A SHORTCUT THROUGH TIME: The Path to the Quantum Computer. By George Johnson. (Knopf, $24.) A science writer and veteran explainer communicates some of the propositions offered by theorists about the virtually unlimited computing power that may follow certain practical triumphs that are not quite in sight.
A SHORT HISTORY OF NEARLY EVERYTHING. By Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $27.50.) Neither oversimplified nor overstuffed, this exceptionally skillful tour of the physical world covers the basic principles and still has room for profiles of some of the more engaging scientists, like Isaac Newton, who (literally) stuck a needle in his eye.
SONGBOOK. By Nick Hornby. (McSweeney's, $26; a CD is included.) A small, singular, delightful collection of 26 essays by a music freak, each devoted to one or two pop recordings, trying to cope with the power of songs to bind people culturally and to reach deeply into the human spirit, bending the heart into new shapes with new potentials.
SPEAKING OF BEAUTY. By Denis Donoghue. (Yale University, $24.95.) A book of practical criticism that is also an enactment of cultural studies, allowing 20th-century literary theorists on board without giving them the wheel; Donoghue, as his title shows, has not abandoned the idea that some things of human making are superior to some other such things.
THE SPECKLED PEOPLE. By Hugo Hamilton. (Fourth Estate, $24.95.) A painful, funny memoir, told from a young boy's point of view, about growing up in a household at odds with the world around it. Hamilton, the son of a German mother and an Irish father, was taunted as a "Nazi" in postwar Dublin and ridiculed for his father's crusade to de-Anglicize Ireland.
STAN AND OLLIE. The Roots of Comedy: The Double Life of Laurel and Hardy. By Simon Louvish. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $27.95.) An informative biography of two of Hollywood's masters of comic mayhem; Louvish charts a partnership that spanned three decades (1921-51), produced more than 100 films and survived the transition from silent film to sound.
THE STORY OF MY FATHER: A Memoir. By Sue Miller. (Knopf, $22.50.) A familiar but still touching story of a parent's descent into Alzheimer's disease; the deeper Miller's father sinks into confusion, the more powerfully candid her writing becomes.
THE STORYTELLER'S DAUGHTER. By Saira Shah. (Knopf, $24.) A brilliant and moving memoir by the journalist who narrated the documentary "Beneath the Veil," a daughter of a distinguished Afghan expatriate family; she grew up in England but is often homesick for Afghanistan, where, she believes, Western interference blows hot and cold and inopportunely.
THE STUFF OF LIFE: A Daughter's Memoir. By Karen Karbo. (Bloomsbury, $24.95.) A painful memoir of her difficult father's decline and death from cancer, by a novelist and magazine writer who had to take care of him, and also had to despair of taking care of him; from this she saw that the heart doesn't break clean and the dying depart from you long before they die.
THE SUBSTANCE OF STYLE: How the Rise of Aesthetic Value Is Remaking Commerce, Culture, and Consciousness. By Virginia Postrel. (HarperCollins, $24.95.) An overview of what Postrel, an Economic Scene columnist for The Times, calls "the aesthetic age," in which style matters as much as substance and is rooted not in market manipulation but in "fundamental, biologically based human wants."
TALES OF INNOCENCE AND EXPERIENCE: An Exploration. By Eva Figes. (Bloomsbury, $23.95.) There is a poetic delicacy -- but nothing cute -- about this British writer's account of grandparenthood, which is also a story of Figes' escape from Nazi Germany to England in 1939.
THE TEAMMATES. By David Halberstam. (Hyperion, $22.95.) An elegant account of the lives and friendships of four legendary Boston Red Sox: Ted Williams, Dominic DiMaggio, Johnny Pesky and Bobby Doerr; the story unfolds in a series of flashbacks as DiMaggio and Pesky drive 1,300 miles to Florida to visit the ailing Williams.
TERROR AND LIBERALISM. By Paul Berman. (Norton, $21.) This personal manifesto by a liberal interventionist tries to chart a course between right-wing "realists" and left-wing "anti-imperialists" now that the totalitarian mental modes of Communism and fascism have been inherited chiefly by angry Muslims.
TERROR IN THE NAME OF GOD: Why Religious Militants Kill. By Jessica Stern. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $27.95.) By talking over four years to hard-line haters around the globe, from Hamas to American Identity Christians to Jews who think the United States conspires against Israel, Stern finds many invincible convictions held by groups that differ chiefly in whom they think God loves the most.
TESTAMENT: A Soldier's Story of the Civil War. By Benson Bobrick. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A versatile historian constructs this portrait of one of his own great-grandfathers, a Union soldier in the Civil War; based on a collection of his letters from 1861 to 1864, it shows a likable, brave, selfless young man worn weary by time and family casualties.
THEY MARCHED INTO SUNLIGHT: War and Peace, Vietnam and America, October 1967. By David Maraniss. (Simon & Schuster, $29.95.) A big narrative by a reporter who juxtaposes a ghastly little battle in Vietnam with an antiwar and anti-Dow demonstration at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, on the same two days. Marianiss captures moral conviction and moral ambiguity everywhere, without stereotyping or condescension.
THINGS MY MOTHER NEVER TOLD ME. By Blake Morrison. (Granta, $24.95.) An ambitious epistolary memoir, drawing on a big cache of letters exchanged by Morrison's parents during World War II. Eavesdropping on their courtship lets him produce a remarkable home-front atmosphere with a special focus on his mother's concealment of her Irish origins.
A TIME OF OUR CHOOSING: America's War in Iraq. By Todd S. Purdum and the staff of The New York Times. (Times Books/Holt, $25.) A guide to the causes, conduct and consequences, deftly woven by Purdum into a coherent narrative; with a chronology since 9/11/01.
TRIANGLE: The Fire That Changed America. By David Von Drehle. (Atlantic Monthly, $25.) An account of the Triangle Waist Company fire in Manhattan in 1911, which killed 146 garment workers and led to reformed labor laws in New York; the author, a Washington Post reporter, provides a detailed background portrait of the city and the times.
TWENTIETH-CENTURY ATTITUDES: Literary Powers in Uncertain Times. By Brooke Allen. (Ivan R. Dee, $26.) Allen's tart, entertaining collection of essays, many of which originally appeared in The New Criterion, deals as much with the lives of writers as with their work.
ULTIMATE FITNESS: The Quest for Truth About Exercise and Health. By Gina Kolata. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) Tracing the country's fitness craze and the science behind it, Kolata, a science reporter for The Times, taps into her own obsession with exercise, tempering skepticism with a refreshingly honest mixture of vanity, hedonism and hope of longevity.
UNDER THE BANNER OF HEAVEN: A Story of Violent Faith. By Jon Krakauer. (Doubleday, $26.) An arresting portrait of Mormon fundamentalism -- and, by extension, the spiraling of fundamentalism into violence -- centered on the crime of Dan and Ron Lafferty, who killed their brother's wife and infant daughter in 1984, and claimed they had acted on direct orders from God.
AN UNFINISHED LIFE: John F. Kennedy, 1917-1963. By Robert Dallek. (Little, Brown, $30.) Granted access to Kennedy's private medical records, Dallek, a presidential historian at Boston University, looks unflinchingly at a presidency and a man who was (and still is) the model of youthful vigor despite an assortment of physical problems.
UNTANGLING MY CHOPSTICKS: A Culinary Sojourn in Kyoto. By Victoria Abbot Riccardi. (Broadway, $23.95.) Riccardi, a trained chef and disaffected New Yorker, spent a year in Kyoto studying kaiseki, the ceremonial tea cuisine developed by Buddhist monks as a guide toward meditation and enlightenment.
A VENETIAN AFFAIR. By Andrea di Robilant. (Knopf, $24.) Di Robilant elicits, from family documents, an engrossing love story of the 18th century, about one of his aristocratic ancestors and a beautiful, intelligent woman who was altogether unsuitable to the family.
W. B. YEATS: A Life. Volume 2: The Arch-Poet, 1915-1939. By R. F. Foster. (Oxford University, $45.) Chosen by Yeats's family in 1985, when he was 36, Foster concludes his life of the great Irish poet, revolutionary and revelation seeker; Foster is a wise and ingenious reader of the poems and is particularly good on the relationship with George Hyde Lees and the automatic writings.
W. C. FIELDS: A Biography. By James Curtis. (Knopf, $35.) A scrupulous, sympathetic life of the great performer who projected in his characters -- sly, blustering, bibulous loners protecting themselves with a smoke screen of gab -- reflections of real human nature as he had observed it for himself.
WHAT EVERY PERSON SHOULD KNOW ABOUT WAR. By Chris Hedges. (Free Press, paper, $11.) An arresting, peculiar, amply footnoted little book that deals, in Q. and A. form, with issues like "What are the most common forms of physical torture?"; by a Times reporter who has covered several wars.
WHEELS FOR THE WORLD: Henry Ford, His Company, and a Century of Progress, 1903-2003. By Douglas Brinkley. (Viking, $34.95.) A mighty, sprawling narrative synthesis focused on the family, especially Henry I, an American original who knew how to get people to do what he wanted done.
WHEN HOLLYWOOD HAD A KING: The Reign of Lew Wasserman, Who Leveraged Talent Into Power and Influence. By Connie Bruck. (Random House, $29.95.) A methodical portrait of the great chief of MCA, a secretive mogul whose vindictiveness and cunning was well matched by his shrewdness and prescience.
WHERE I WAS FROM. By Joan Didion. (Knopf, $23.) In a radically revisionary assessment of her home and her opinions, Didion gives up on California and its inhabitants, including her own pioneer family; she now sees the state's history as a fiasco, a saga of advancement with other people's money, chiefly the government's, spent on behalf of business interests.
THE WHITE ROCK: An Exploration of the Inca Heartland. By Hugh Thomson. (Overlook, $27.95.) The author's account of his successful quest to discover a lost ruin in the intractable Peruvian Andes, with an architecturally informed analysis of the Incas' penchant for mountain landscapes and for responding creatively to them.
WHY AMERICA SLEPT: The Failure to Prevent 9/11. By Gerald Posner. (Random House, $24.95.) Posner has built a reputation for debunking popular conspiracy theories, but here he offers a provocative one of his own: Saudi Arabia was a partner to Al Qaeda in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
YOGA FOR PEOPLE WHO CAN'T BE BOTHERED TO DO IT. By Geoff Dyer. (Pantheon, $22.) A delightful counterguide by a countertourist, who has visited the classic loci -- Paris, Bali, Rome, New Orleans -- without seeing a sight or snapping a picture. The author, who by the end of his travels is in his early 40's, looks everywhere for states of mind attainable through drugs or through ancient ruins.
ZORA NEALE HURSTON: A Life in Letters. Edited by Carla Kaplan. (Doubleday, $40.) Nearly 900 pages clarify some of Hurston's views about art and politics yet cannot unlock the true heart of an infinitely inventive black writer who posed as different things to different people.

MYSTERIES
THE BABES IN THE WOOD. By Ruth Rendell. (Crown, $25.) Supple prose, intricate plotting and an ominous atmosphere draw us into this disquieting case of Chief Inspector Wexford, involving two teenagers who disappear during ferocious rainstorms that flood Kingsmarkham and drench the story with intimations of nature's dark forces raging out of control.
DONE FOR A DIME. By David Corbett. (Ballantine, $24.95.) The death of an old jazz musician, the axman for legends like Bobby Blue Bland and King Curtis, sounds the blue note of this dazzling novel, narrated in the blunt and vigorous idiom of California noir but full of compassion for marginal people whose rights are trampled upon by power brokers.
FEAR ITSELF. By Walter Mosley. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Paris Minton, the lily-livered bookstore owner who wouldn't last a minute on the rough streets of Los Angeles without his deadly friend, Fearless Jones, invites trouble by trying to help a frantic mother locate the runaway father of her child, in a noir tale driven by its high-stepping, fast-talking characters.
HEX. By Maggie Estep. (Three Rivers, paper, $14.) Ruby Murphy, the Coney Island drifter whose free spirit accounts for the ravishing originality of this idiosyncratic first mystery, falls for a perfect stranger's sob story and goes undercover as a stablehand at Belmont Park to keep tabs on a stable groom with sexy eyes and a mysterious past.
MAISIE DOBBS. By Jacqueline Winspear. (Soho, $24.) The resourceful heroine of this haunting first novel applies her experiences as a battlefield nurse in World War I to her new career as a private investigator, scandalizing society but offering a humane psychological approach to a harrowing case involving physically and mentally shattered war veterans.
RESURRECTION MEN. By Ian Rankin. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) It could just be John Rebus's paranoia kicking in again, but the abrasive Edinburgh cop suspects he is under internal surveillance when he is taken off a murder investigation for remedial training at the Scottish Police College, along with five other officers in need of an attitude overhaul.
SOUL CIRCUS. By George P. Pelecanos. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Fascinated with the way crime actually works, Pelecanos takes apart the gun trade like an urban anthropologist, fitting the pieces into the thriving drug industry and gang culture of a Washington neighborhood where enterprising criminals work hard to make a dishonest living.

SCIENCE FICTION
ALTERED CARBON. By Richard K. Morgan. (Del Rey/Ballantine, paper, $13.95.) In this rousing first novel, Morgan reimagines Chandler's "Big Sleep" as 25th-century noir, with a Philip Marlowe-esque protagonist trying to avoid "real death" in a world where serial resurrection is a privilege of the rich and ruthless.
BLIND LAKE. By Robert Charles Wilson. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $24.95.) A genre-stretching first-contact-with-aliens story that begins with interstellar eavesdropping and ends with a new level of cosmic intimacy.
CHANGING PLANES. By Ursula K. Le Guin. (Harcourt, $22.) Philosophical fiction in the manner of Jonathan Swift and Jorge Luis Borges; dispensing with the technojargon of science fiction, Le Guin offers a grand tour of imaginary societies whose governing principles range from inspiring to disgusting to almost unbearably poignant.
EVOLUTION. By Stephen Baxter. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $25.95.) In a work of outrageous ambition, Baxter sets out to dramatize the grand sweep of primate development, from a rodent-like Eve scrabbling for survival in the dinosaur-dominated forests of North America 65 million years ago to an imaginary whimper some 500 million years in the future. He comes closer to succeeding than seems humanly possible.
GRASS FOR HIS PILLOW. By Lian Hearn. (Riverhead, $24.95.) Set in a medieval Japan of the imagination, the deliciously readable sequel to "Across the Nightingale Floor" continues the story of Otori Takeo and his lover Kaede, who must exercise their considerable powers to withstand the manifold forces arrayed against them.
THE PHOENIX EXULTANT and THE GOLDEN TRANSCENDENCE: Or, the Last of the Masquerade. By John C. Wright. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $24.95 and $25.95.) Books 2 and 3 of a philosophical space opera that follows the efforts of a multitalented hero named Phaethon to return a sense of adventure to a self-satisfied utopia that commands almost unlimited power.
THE X PRESIDENT. By Philip Baruth. (Bantam, paper, $11.95.) History won't stand still in this clever time-travel romp about mid-21st-century spooks who try to unmake a war by changing a presidential decision in the past. The president in question, identified throughout as "BC," appears as a 16-year-old boy and a 109-year-old man.

CHILDREN'S BOOKS
ALICE'S ADVENTURES IN WONDERLAND: A Pop-Up Adaptation of Lewis Carroll's Original Tale. Illustrated by Robert Sabuda. (Little Simon/Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) (All ages) A faithful adaptation of the original text is combined with intelligent paper trickery, and the result is worth reading and playing with repeatedly and often. 
ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT. Written and illustrated by Laurie Keller. (Holt, $16.95.) (Ages 4 to 8) This book about a wide-eyed young hero with a plain name and decent nature is filled with visual and verbal delights as it follows the adventures of a doughnut.
A DAY IN THE LIFE OF MURPHY. Written and illustrated by Alice Provensen. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) (Ages 3 to 7) "Murphy-Stop-That is my name" says the terrier narrator, rushing and yapping from dawn till well after dark. He practically jumpsoff the page and is a total delight.
THE DAY THE BABIES CRAWLED AWAY. Written and illustrated by Peggy Rathmann. (Putnam, $16.99.) (All ages) An enchanting adventure told in verse, and seen entirely in silhouette illustrations set against a color-changing sky. The babies crawl away from a party and are rescued by a brave boy in a fireman's hat.
THE MAN WHO WALKED BETWEEN THE TOWERS. (Roaring Brook, $17.95.) (Ages 5 and up) A stunning account of Philippe Petit's stroll between the towers of the World Trade Center in 1974, including double-page spreads that are "terrifying and beautiful."
MORRIS THE ARTIST. By Lore Segal. Illustrated by Boris Kulikov. (Frances Foster/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.) (Ages 4 to 8) Morris is a reluctant guest at another child's birthday party. His "self-obsession knows no bounds," but his artistic impulses win out and turn a mere party into a glorious celebration.
THE TREE OF LIFE: A Book Depicting the Life of Charles Darwin, Naturalist, Geologist & Thinker. Written and illustrated by Peter Sis. (Frances Foster/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.) (Ages 8 and up) This work succeeds brilliantly in arresting and educating the eye in the way it presents the life and work of the great scientist.
WHEN EVERYBODY WORE A HAT. Written and illustrated by William Steig. (Joanna Cotler/HarperCollins, $17.99.) (Ages 4 and up) A witty memoir in pictures by the great artist and storyteller who died in October.

HEADLINE: The Week Ahead; 
ECONOMY

BYLINE:  By Edmund L. Andrews

 BODY:
 The American economy has moved into high gear, and job creation is finally beginning to pick up, but the Federal Reserve is not about to declare victory. The Fed's monetary policy committee, which meets Tuesday, is all but certain to leave the federal funds rate for overnight loans between banks at just 1 percent, the lowest level in 45 years. 
Most analysts also predict the Fed will repeat its open-ended commitment to keep policy loose "for a considerable period." 
 Fed officials want to see a bigger decline in unemployment, and were probably not impressed by news on Friday that the jobless rate edged down to 5.9 percent from 6.0 percent. As for inflation, Fed officials still appear to be more worried about prices going down than up. Edmund L. Andrews

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 4147 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE 

BYLINE:  By Martin Filler; Martin Filler is the architecture critic of The New Republic and frequently writes for The New York Review of Books and House & Garden magazine.

 BODY:
SYMPHONY: Frank Gehry's Walt Disney Concert Hall. Essays by Richard Koshalek et al. Photographs by Grant Mudford. (Abrams in association with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, $60.) 
 FOG: Flowing in All Directions. (CIRCA/Museum of Contemporary Art, $75.) If Frank Gehry could be compared to a character by Walt Disney, for whom the architect's magnificent new concert hall in Los Angeles is named, it would be Mickey Mouse as the sorcerer's apprentice in "Fantasia." Just as the magician's assistant was overwhelmed by the proliferating brooms and pails he conjured up but could not control, so Gehry, in the aftermath of his watershed Guggenheim Museum Bilbao, has struggled to keep pace with exponentially expanding demands on his time and talent. Some people wondered whether his newfound power was actually a curse: how could he pull another one out of his hat like his Spanish marvel? 
 Proof that Gehry has exceeded his earlier triumph is plentiful in "Symphony: Frank Gehry's Walt Disney Concert Hall," a handsome monograph published to coincide with the auditorium's opening in October. This collection of writings by several of the project's principals -- including the architect and Esa-Pekka Salonen, the Los Angeles Philharmonic's music director -- is supplemented by essays that discuss the building in its architectural and urban contexts. In their recounting of this problem-plagued 16-year commission (begun before Bilbao), Richard Koshalek, a member of the selection panel that recommended Gehry, and Diana Hutt, an architectural historian, tell the truth but not the whole truth. Though it isn't expected that commemorative tributes like this serve as exposes, the authors' overly sanitized version of an instructive creative struggle leaves too much to be explained. The record the book offers is worthy, but selective.
Grant Mudford's exceptional color photographs of the construction process and the sublime finished product illustrate why this is unquestionably the building of the year. Clad in a shimmering skin of stainless steel, the hall's voluptuous, swirling forms evoke the contours of full-blown sails tacking in the wind, but Gehry rises above literal representation and ascends into poetic abstraction. He has given Los Angeles its long-awaited crowning glory. 
The excitement of Gehry's newest architecture is palpable in "FOG: Flowing in All Directions," which accompanies "Frank O. Gehry: Work in Progress," an exhibition of 11 recent projects on view at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles through Jan. 26. This vibrantly offbeat catalog, designed by Tracey Shiffman, features Daniel Joseph Martinez's arresting head shots of the architect, his partners and office staff, among them his wife, Berta (administration), and son Alejandro (product design). Though Gehry is today's architectural superstar, more than many of his peers he acknowledges the collaborative nature of his medium, and this collegial portrait gallery confers much deserved visibility on his devoted teammates. 
PARIS: City of Art. By Jean-Marie Perouse de Montclos. (Vendome, $85.) Weighing a hefty 11 pounds, this surpassingly rich visual and intellectual feast is the luxury book bargain of the season. With a tone at once magisterial and personal, learned but accessible, the historian and curator Jean-Marie Perouse de Montclos (well served by a sympathetic squadron of translators) conducts a stately promenade through the 23 centuries since a Celtic people called the Parisii settled on the Seine's Ile de la Cite. Though the work's subtitle leads one to believe that its subject is painting and sculpture, which are indeed fully represented, its primary theme is the architecture of the City of Light, and rarely has it shone more brightly on the printed page.
Perouse de Montclos's method of examining landmarks individually and in depth opens our eyes to treasures that even habitues of Paris may have missed. On my next trip there I plan to seek out the city's largest ancient ruin, the great Roman baths on the Left Bank, dating from the turn of the third century, when the town was called Lutetia. Also unfamiliar to me was the 18th-century Saint-James Folly in Neuilly, a romantic caprice juxtaposing a serene Classical portico against a faux grotto of rough-hewn boulders. And I can't wait to see Louis-Auguste Boileau's neo-Gothic Church of Saint-Eugene and Sainte-Cecile, consecrated in 1855, a riot of color and pattern with slender, painted cast-iron columns supporting vividly hued vaults aglitter with gilt stars. This overwhelming, surprise-packed compendium brings to mind a Cole Porter lyric: "You may know Paris, but you don't know Paree."
BUTABU: Adobe Architecture of West Africa. By James Morris. Text by Suzanne Preston Blier. (Princeton Architectural Press, $50.) The British photographer James Morris easily takes the palm for the year's most haunting architectural images with this album of the baked mud buildings of Benin, Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger. These sensuously hand-modeled and boldly painted structures -- incorporating distantly perceived elements from Islamic and European traditions along with wholly spontaneous outbursts of indigenous invention -- mix the raw vitality of folk art with the mad flights of imagination generally ascribed to high-style mavericks like Gaudi or Gehry. 
One wonders how long Morris had to tarry to achieve such luminous gradations of light and atmosphere in these breathtaking pictures. The graceful way in which he incorporates human and animal figures into his compositions -- helpfully, because the scale of these idiosyncratic buildings is difficult for the untutored eye to gauge without them -- adds immeasurably to their engaging humanity and exquisite strangeness.
VILLAS OF TUSCANY. Text by Carlo Cresti. Photographs by Massimo Listri. (Vendome, $50.) 
ITALIAN VILLAS. Text and photography by Ovidio Guaita. (Abbeville, $75.) There seems to be no end to the enduring spell that the northern Italian countryside casts over some people's imaginative lives. It is that perpetual audience of well-heeled, well-read, well-traveled romantics -- the "Room With a View," "Enchanted April" and "Under the Tuscan Sun" crowd -- that the publishers of these sumptuous books obviously have in mind. Carlo Cresti and Massimo Listri's "Villas of Tuscany" is marginally more appealing. However, Ovidio Guaita's "Italian Villas" shows American novices the important regional distinctions that make the grand country house in foggy Piedmont a very different thing from what it is in sunny Sicily. It also contains a helpful comparative gazetteer illustrating local renditions of building components common throughout Italy. 
NICHOLAS HAWKSMOOR: Rebuilding Ancient Wonders. By Vaughan Hart. (Paul Mellon Center/Yale University, $60.) Overshadowed during his lifetime by the commanding Sir Christopher Wren, for whom he worked on St. Paul's Cathedral, Nicholas Hawksmoor in the long view of history seems quite the more interesting architect. Hawksmoor's quirky, vigorous variations on well-worn classical themes gave London several of its most remarkable religious edifices, planned between 1714 and 1730. His Christ Church Spitalfields is a convincing pileup of gutsy improvisations derived from published sources but then deliciously twisted. Those clever adaptations include a projecting portico with a central barrel vault flanked by Tuscan columns, transposed from the tripartite window format usually called Palladian but in fact cribbed from the Renaissance master Sebastiano Serlio. My favorite is St. Mary Woolnoth. Its forceful geometric facade, deeply scored with horizontal rustication, sets the stage for Etienne-Louis Boullee and Claude-Nicolas Ledoux's protomodern classicism late in that century. 
Vaughan Hart, who teaches architectural history at the University of Bath, does a commendable job with this first in-depth study of Hawksmoor in almost 45 years. Hart stresses the contrast between the architect's fiercely adventurous aesthetic -- derided by the play-it-by-the-book Palladians who dominated English patronage during the diminished late phase of his career -- and his calm, unassuming personality. He endured galling professional setbacks and crippling attacks of gout with the same philosophical equanimity, if not acquiescence.
YIN YU TANG: The Architecture and Daily Life of a Chinese House. By Nancy Berliner. (Tuttle, $34.95.) Museum houses can be dry and lifeless things. Not so with the most thrilling reconstitution of a foreign structure brought to America in many years. A classic country courtyard house of the Qing dynasty, Yin Yu Tang (the three words respectively mean shade/shelter, abundance and hall) was built around 1800 by a merchant clan in Huang Cun, a remote village in the Huizhou region of China's Anhui province. In 1996 the forsaken relic was about to be sold, and in all likelihood demolished, when Nancy Berliner, now curator of Chinese art at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass., chanced upon it and set in motion its astonishing international journey. 
The Peabody Essex owns a number of historic houses, some of which have been moved to its campus, but the possibility of adding one from the Far East and dating to the zenith of the China trade, Salem's major source of wealth, seemed no less than providential. The complex tale of Yin Yu Tang's salvation, careful dismantling, painstaking reconstruction and authentic refurnishing at the New England institution is alluded to in a brief epilogue.
But it is the profoundly moving saga of the Huang family, generations of whom lived and died in Yin Yu Tang, that raises this above a routine preservation success story. The many woes that have racked China and its resilient people over centuries cannot but arouse our empathy for the valiant Huangs, whose ancestral residence became a palimpsest of those wider tribulations. Their touching and uplifting stories, told in the first person through letters, diaries and interviews, confirm how the psychic relationship between house and home is by far the most elemental function of architecture.
SEA-CAPTAINS' HOUSES AND ROSE-COVERED COTTAGES: The Architectural Heritage of Nantucket Island. By Margaret Moore Booker, Rose Gonnella and Patricia Egan Butler. (Universe in association with the Egan Institute of Maritime Studies, $45.) The innate and seemingly infallible wisdom of American vernacular construction in the 18th and 19th centuries is underscored on every page of this informative but cautionary survey of building traditions on Nantucket. Always less luxurious and sophisticated than the architecture of Massachusetts's international trading port of Salem, the Nantucket style was provincial in the best sense, expressing a forthright simplicity that observed all the niceties of good taste and proper proportion. 
After Nantucket prospered during the high tide of the whaling industry -- clean-burning whale oil was the preferred fuel for indoor illumination before natural gas -- it went into steep economic decline and entered a long period of benign neglect that happily kept its original character intact. The island's fortunes revived at the turn of the last century when it was rediscovered by appreciative summer vacationers, including many artists, writers and actors who found it an unspoiled time capsule of a vanished America. 
Preserving the low-key qualities that make Nantucket so charming has been no easy task over the past few decades, yet efforts to enforce restrictions on the style, scale, materials and color of new construction have been largely successful. Though this now fashionable destination has been spared the widespread depredations that have engulfed the South Fork of Long Island, it too has its share of late-model trophy houses. The owners of Travis Price's postmodern Gamble house of 1989 on Pocomo Point willnot be overjoyed to see their showy Colonial-pastiche summer place illustrated as a textbook example of how not to live in harmony with three centuries of intelligently evolved design. 
THOMAS JECKYLL: Architect and Designer, 1827-1881. By Susan Weber Soros and Catherine Arbuthnott. (Bard Graduate Center/Yale University, $85.) Ever since she founded the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, Design and Culture in New York City 10 years ago, its director, Susan Weber Soros, an art historian and philanthropist, has been rewriting history. The exemplary exhibitions she has mounted at the center's Upper West Side gallery, and the publications produced in conjunction with them, have expanded scholarship and deepened understanding of the decorative arts, particularly 19th-century European design.
The latest of Soros's admirable rediscoveries is the British architect and designer Thomas Jeckyll, subject of a retrospective at the Bard Graduate Center Gallery earlier this year. Starting out in the Gothic Revival style like his older contemporary A. W. N. Pugin (given a Bard show in 1996), Jeckyll set sail for the wilder shores of the Aesthetic Movement, that improbable Victorian amalgam of Far Eastern, medieval and Queen Anne influences.
An architect of talent but a decorator of genius, Jeckyll collaborated most memorably with James McNeill Whistler on the blue-and-gold Peacock Room, created in 1875-76 for the London mansion of the industrialist Frederick Leyland. Conceived as a showcase for Leyland's collection of blue-and-white porcelain, this shelf-bedecked dining salon (now reinstalled at the Freer Gallery in Washington) unites architecture, painting and applied arts in an inseparable whole that comes closer than any other domestic interior to the 19th-century ideal of Gesamtkunstwerk, the all-encompassing work of art. Its playful exoticism, subversive humor and innate Englishness (even in Japanesque drag) make it the decorative equivalent of "The Mikado," written a decade afterward.
Sadly, Jeckyll's mental health collapsed the year he completed the Peacock Room, and he spent his remaining half decade in and out of asylums. In the first monograph on this fascinating figure, Soros and her co-author, Catherine Arbuthnott, resurrect from unwarranted obscurity a design polymath of immensely fertile imagination.
MODERNISMO: Architecture and Design in Catalonia. Essays by Borja de Riquer i Permanyer et al. Photographs by Marc Llimargas et al. (Monacelli, $75.) It's not hard to assemble a superficially striking group of images spotlighting the bizarre splendors of Modernismo, the Catalan variant of Art Nouveau that blossomed like a fabulous hothouse mutant in and around Barcelona at the turn of the 20th century. Last year several new picture books marked the sesquicentennial of the birth of Antoni Gaudi, the movement's best-known exponent, but only one of them, with a penetrating text by the late Ignasi de Sola-Morales, is outstanding. 
This more comprehensive survey of Gaudi and his wildly experimental contemporaries -- with tongue-twisting names unfamiliar even to some specialists, like Joan Hervas Arizmendi, Juli Batllevell i Arus, and Lluis Muncunill i Parellada -- is extraordinary by any standard. The art direction, regrettably uncredited, dramatically captures the extravagant eruptions of fantasy that made Modernismo the most outre of the diverse international approaches to the free style of circa 1900. 
The uncanny, hallucinatory quality of undulating roofs, etiolated turrets, writhing columns and bulging walls swarming with knobby tiles, biomorphic terra cottas and kaleidoscopic mosaics puts the crafts-enraptured Catalans who summoned up these amazing visions in a class of their own. Rather than lazily dazzling the reader, this serious though seductively disguised volume is underpinned by a veritable academy of Modernismo scholars whose thoughtful essays emphasize that Gaudi was but part of a dense network of some of the most imaginative architects ever crowded together in one small but towering city. 
McKIM, MEAD & WHITE: The Masterworks. By Samuel G. White and Elizabeth White. Photographs by Jonathan Wallen. (Rizzoli, $75.) Finicky critics might quibble about this book's hyperbolic subtitle -- not every building here deserves the lofty honorific of masterwork -- but enough impressive landmarks survive to demonstrate why a century ago McKim, Mead & White reigned as the design dream team of the American establishment. Just as the United States began to emerge as a world power, this New York-based firm supplied cities across the country with a new and flattering public image neatly conflating historical precedent, aesthetic cultivation and imperial grandeur. 
Its influence grew so pervasive that its accomplished brand of Beaux-Arts Classicism spelled disaster for several architectural individualists, mainly the infinitely more original Frank Furness and Louis Sullivan. With tragic consequences for himself, Sullivan presciently predicted that the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago, in which the partnership played a significant role, would retard the advance of innovative architecture in America for 50 years.
Graciously designed by Marcus Ratliff, this generous volume is a welcome sequel to "The Houses of McKim, Mead & White," by Samuel G. White, a New York architect and a great-grandson of Stanford White, star of that legendary troika. He and his wife and co-author, Elizabeth White, move chronologically from such shingle-style delights as Rhode Island's Newport Casino, through the Roman monumentality of Columbia University's Low Library, on to such late oddities as New York's pinnacled, high-rise Municipal Building, which seems to foretell Stalinist Classicism. With a keen sense of social history, the authors help bring alive the milieus in which McKim, Mead and White's scintillating and synthetic art flourished.
GUIDE TO NEW YORK CITY LANDMARKS: Third Edition. Text by Andrew S. Dolkart and Matthew A. Postal. (Wiley, paper, $24.95.)
NEW YORK: Architecture & Design. Edited and written by Hubertus Adam. (teNeues, $12.95.) For a city that's been building itself up and tearing itself down with alarming alacrity almost from the beginning, New York, it's heartening to know, since 1965 has put more than 1,100 structures under the legal protection of its Landmark Preservation Commission. This latest update of the indispensable official guidebook to those hardy urban survivors includes some 150 structures in all five boroughs designated during the 11 years since the first edition appeared. They range from La Casina, a snazzy little Streamlined Moderne nightclub in Jamaica, Queens, to the Gothic Revival row house on Manhattan's Avenue B where the jazz legend Charlie Parker once lived. (Louis Armstrong's equally modest house in Corona, Queens, was landmarked in 1988 and opened to visitors this fall.)
I was glad to find 240 Central Park South, an underappreciated Columbus Circle apartment building of 1939-40 by the New York modern housing experts Albert Mayer and Julian Whittlesey, designated last year. The new entries, deftly written by the architectural historian Matthew A. Postal, nicely complement the crisp text from earlier editions by the architectural historian Andrew S. Dolkart, updated by Postal.
Critics constantly complain about the dearth of good new architecture here, but the encouraging evidence provided by "New York: Architecture & Design" indicates that things are looking up. Although several of the 73 recent projects in this useful handbook are either still in the planning stage (Norman Foster's Hearst headquarters) or under construction (Yoshio Taniguchi's Museum of Modern Art expansion), there are enough completed works to keep both residents and tourists traveling around town for days.
Here as elsewhere, the museum remains the signal building type of our period. Tod Williams and Billie Tsien's superb American Folk Art Museum, which opened in 2001, takes a narrow Midtown, midblock site and alchemizes it into a soaring, inward-turning space that feels absolutely colossal. Michael Maltzan's ramp-wrapped entry hall at MoMA Queens is invigoratingly kinetic. Inexplicably absent is Annabelle Selldorf's meticulous conversion of a Beaux-Arts Fifth Avenue mansion into the gemlike Neue Galerie, which, although it is an adaptive reuse, certainly counts as first-rate contemporary architecture.
The text (in English, French, German and Spanish) is terse to the point of parody and sidesteps value judgments. Is Arquitectonica's Westin Hotel of 2002 near Times Square the ugliest thing built in Manhattan in ages, or does it pay appropriate homage to the area's honky-tonk spirit? The author, Hubertus Adam, a German architecture critic, doesn't say, but chronically opinionated New Yorkers will have no trouble appending their own pithy epithets. 
TADAO ANDO: Light and Water. (Monacelli, $65.) The self-taught Japanese master Tadao Ando, today's pre-eminent architectural minimalist, is no intellectual theorist. This stunning roundup of 35 favorite projects, selected by the architect, is unrolled as one gorgeous spread after another, and why not? Several excellent photographers, principally Mitsuo Matsuoka, prove that the camera loves Ando's work, and understandably so, for his deployment of strong geometric forms under vivid natural illumination is unsurpassed. 
Ando's acclaimed chapels and museums possess an undeniable and interchangeable spirituality that transcends functional intent, and either God or art might be reasonably worshiped in either. Not since Luis Barragan, a comparably inspired minimalist, has any designer better understood how water can be integrated into an architectural composition, and Ando exploits the paradoxical opposition of solid and liquid with great emotional impact. Matsuoka excels at conveying the sensuality of his reflecting pools, water channels and fountains, as well as the surprisingly varied effects he can achieve within a narrow range of materials -- primarily concrete, but also glass, steel and wood. At once thoroughly cosmopolitan yet at heart consummately Japanese, Ando's universally grounded architecture suggests that globalization need not equate with cultural homogenization.
BEHIND THE GATES: Life, Security, and the Pursuit of Happiness in Fortress America. By Setha Low. (Routledge, $26.) The bias toward theory that now dominates architectural discourse leaves little room for the sociological considerations once advanced by influential critics like Lewis Mumford and Jane Jacobs, especially in urban planning. 
With this intriguingly inferential investigation of the growing phenomenon of the gated community, SethaLow, a professor of anthropology and environmental psychology at the CUNY Graduate Center, might prompt her colleagues in the social sciences to fill the vacuum left by present-day architectural commentators. 
Secured housing developments are transforming suburbia; some 16 million people live in them, mainly in the Sun Belt. During eight years of ethnographic research, Low visited restricted-access enclaves around the country, interviewed residents and found that despite a concurrent drop in crime nationwide, motivations for moving to them are tellingly similar. She cites "desire for safety, security, community and 'niceness,' as well as wanting to live near people like themselves because of a fear of 'others' and of crime."
As the United States becomes increasingly multicultural and nonwhite, gated communities have the inevitable effect, Low argues, of deepening racial and class divisions. Ironically, that segregation can make those compounds' residents, particularly the young, feel more insecure outside their gates as they become less accustomed to mixing with the general population.
Low does not mince words in analyzing her troublesome findings: "The creation of gated communities (and the addition of guardhouses, walls and entrance gates to established neighborhoods) is an integral part of the building of the fortress city, a social control technique based on the so-called militarization of the city. In America it is a strategy for regulating and patrolling an urban poor comprised predominantly of Latino and black minorities living in ghettos and other deteriorating residential areas. Gating, however, is only one example of this new form of social ordering that conceals, displaces and regulates people or activities rather than eliminating them."
Apart from their more obviously exclusionary aspects, Low finds gated communities insidiously antidemocratic and antisocial because they play into the increasing privatization of all aspects of our society. Many municipal services are now provided by homeowners' associations rather than local government, removing accountability from publicly elected officials. Provocative and disturbing, this much-needed book holds up an unsparing mirror to an unsettling sign of our times.

 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 7, 2003
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 97

LENGTH: 1685 words

HEADLINE: FOOD; 
Kebabing Along

BYLINE:  By Julia Reed

 BODY:
When I went to Afghanistan in August, I was prepared -- sort of -- for the acres of crashed airplane carcasses that greeted us upon arrival at the Kabul International Airport; I was prepared for the heat and the dust and the fact that much of the place is essentially a pile of rubble. I was even prepared for the traffic (just before I left, The Wall Street Journal pointed out that there were almost 200,000 registered vehicles in the city -- and no traffic rules to speak of). What I was not prepared for was the food. It is delicious.
 My Vogue colleague Alexandra Kotur and I were there to cover the Kabul Beauty School, an enterprise that sounded, even to us, not just a little frivolous. But it turns out that beauty salons had been among the few small businesses owned and operated by women before the Taliban gained power, and during the regime, women literally risked their lives to run clandestine salons in their houses. Work was illegal -- curling hair, even with perm rods crudely carved out of wood, was often the only way the women could support their families. 
 The school, which is free, was the brainchild of a gutsy makeup artist and an activist for Afghan widows, and was financed by Vogue and a handful of American cosmetics companies. When we arrived, it had been up and running for a week and was already a huge success. There was a waiting list of more than 100, and the 20 students already enrolled, used to cutting hair with the equivalent of pruning shears, were ecstatic with their new tools and textbooks. They're also given rides to class (they'd never get there if they relied on public transportation) and a hot lunch.
The women, who were for all practical purposes under house arrest under the Taliban, look forward to lunch as an opportunity to socialize. After our first day's offering, a buranee banjan (eggplant cooked with tomatoes and onions in a delicious yogurt sauce), Alexandra and I looked forward to the meal itself. Who knew that in the middle of a dust bowl, farmers could grow scallions two feet long and tomatoes better than East Hampton's in late summer? There is not a lot of visible commerce going on, but produce stands are on almost every block. If it weren't for the exhaust, you could probably smell the bundles of mint and cilantro stacked next to the bags of chickpeas and nuts. Just outside the school, a man appeared every morning with a wagon full of kharbooza, a white-fleshed melon that is possibly the best thing I've ever tasted. (Eli Zabar or Giorgio DeLuca, take note.)
The lunches were cooked by Najia, whose husband was paralyzed in a land-mine explosion, and Mahobha, whose house around the corner provided the stove. They each asked for $40 a month and are paid twice that, plus extra for weekend picnics where the women get together with their teachers (Afghan-Americans who come for three-week stints) and bring their children. We were in town for one that featured shammi kebab, made of chopped cooked meat mixed with split peas, garlic, peppers and spices, and fried, and bowls full of the fabulous tomatoes and cucumbers. I rolled everything up with cilantro and yogurt in a huge slab of warm nan, lay back among the rosebushes the students planted on opening day and thought, briefly, that I was in heaven.
It was not something I would have predicted -- heaven on earth in Kabul -- and believe me, the great majority of scenery could not be accurately described that way. But another little piece of -- relative -- paradise can be found at the Gandamack Lodge, where bin Laden once visited one of his wives. Now it is owned by Peter Jouvenal, a BBC cameraman and an old Afghan hand, who saw an opportunity when the floods of reporters and aid workers began arriving. When I was there, an aristocratic young Brit named Jamie Peck was in charge of the place. The 20-odd guests shared rather disgusting showers, and there was a scorpion in Alexandra's room, but there was not a lot Jamie could do about either of those things. What he did do was keep the place well stocked with booze and wine and very cold beer and develop a menu that another cute Brit named Jamie (Oliver) would be proud to offer. At our first dinner, we got a chilled cucumber soup with fresh dill, roast leg of lamb and an excellent lemon tart. Another night, there was a fish cake -- made of plaice and a little rice with lemon rind, ginger, parsley and cilantro -- accompanied by a tangy chili jam. 
The sophistication of Jamie's operation was astounding. Especially since he was all of 21 with a six-week stint at a cooking school in Somerset under his belt and ambitions to go into hotel management (of real hotels in non-war-torn nations). He figured he'd get good training at the Gandamack -- and certainly more responsibility than he'd have anywhere else -- and he was right. Here he was bossing a 60-something chef named Noor, who spoke no English (Jamie's Dari is spotty at best), and who had been unemployed since the Soviets invaded in 1979. "Most people in this country have lost their skills," Jamie told me. "They don't really know what they're supposed to do, and they have too much pride to tell you that they don't understand what you're asking them. Noor's a good chef, but his nickname's Fishbowl, because he'll learn a recipe and forget it in a week."
Maybe so, but when he does remember, everybody's happy. On our last night, we had risotto cakes with a little ball of mozzarella ingeniously buried inside that melts when it's cooked. The recipe I've given is made with a basic risotto. Jamie and Noor added a pinch of saffron and bits of braised artichoke hearts to theirs (dice about six fresh artichoke hearts, saute them in a little butter and water until the liquid's gone and add them with the onion). It would be equally good with about three or four ounces of diced prosciutto. 

Buranee Banjan
4 medium eggplants (about 1 pound each)
Salt
8 tablespoons olive oil
3 medium onions, finely chopped
2 large ripe tomatoes, peeled, seeded and sliced (or 4 or 5 large plum tomatoes)
1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper or to taste
Yogurt sauce (recipe below)
Fresh mint, finely chopped or torn
Nan or lavash bread for serving.
1. Preheat broiler. Remove the stems from eggplant and cut crosswise into 1/2-inch slices. Select the 24 best slices (not the puffy ends) and discard the rest. Sprinkle slices liberally with salt, leave for 30 minutes, then dry well.
2. Brush slices with 2 tablespoons of olive oil and arrange on cookie sheets. Broil until lightly browned, 2 to 3 minutes per side. (Don't cook the slices completely.)
3. In a deep 12-inch skillet, over medium heat, saute the onions in 6 tablespoons of olive oil for 15 minutes, until reddish brown and juicy but not crisp. Remove to a plate with a slotted spoon.
4. Place 8 rounds of eggplant into the same skillet. Top with half of the chopped onion and tomato slices. Mix 3/4 teaspoon salt and the cayenne in a cup; sprinkle 1/3 over the tomatoes. Repeat with another layer of eggplant and the remaining onions and tomatoes. Sprinkle with half the remaining cayenne mixture. Place an eggplant slice on top of each stack and sprinkle with remaining cayenne. Add 1/4 cup water and cover skillet tightly. Simmer about 30 minutes.
5. To serve: Spread half the yogurt sauce onto the bottom of a serving dish. Top with the vegetables, lifting stacks carefully. Top with the remainder of the yogurt, and drizzle with pan juices. Sprinkle with mint. Serve immediately, with nan or lavash.
Yield: 8 servings.

Yogurt Sauce
2 cups plain whole milk yogurt
2 garlic cloves, peeled and crushed or pushed through a garlic press
Pinch of salt.
Place yogurt in cheesecloth or a muslin-lined strainer and drain over a bowl for 1 hour. Mix with garlic and salt to taste.
Yield: 2 cups.

Risotto Cakes
With Mozzarella
5 cups lightly salted beef or chicken broth
7 tablespoons butter
10 tablespoons olive oil
1 medium onion, finely chopped
2 cups Arborio rice
1/2 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese plus more for serving
1/2 pound fresh mozzarella
2 to 3 eggs
1 cup all-purpose flour
1 1/2 cups fine dried bread crumbs
1/4 teaspoon salt
Homemade tomato sauce, for serving
Fresh marjoram sprigs for garnish.
1. Bring broth to a slow simmer. Put 1 tablespoon butter, 2 tablespoons olive oil and the onion in a heavy saucepan over medium high heat. Stir until onion becomes translucent, about 7 minutes. Add rice and stir to coat well. Add 1/2 cup of the broth, stirring constantly, until almost all the liquid is absorbed. Repeat process, stirring constantly, and adjust heat so mixture simmers but rice does not scorch. After about 20 minutes, nearly all of the stock should be absorbed. Rice should be creamy but firm to the bite. Stir in Parmesan and 2 tablespoons butter.
2. Remove from heat, spread risotto onto a large plate and place in refrigerator for 1/2 hour until firm and chilled. Using a spoon or a melon scooper, make 15 small half balls of the mozzarella. Pack risotto into 1/3-cup measure and invert onto the palm of your hand. Place a half ball of mozzarella in center and press risotto around the ball to make a patty about 2 1/2 inches in diameter and 3/4 inch thick. Make sure risotto covers the cheese. Repeat until you have 15 rice cakes.
3. Place 2 eggs and 2 tablespoons water in a bowl and beat with a fork. Spread flour and bread crumbs on separate plates. Mix salt into bread crumbs. Coat each cake lightly with flour, dip in egg mixture, shake off excess and coat evenly with bread crumbs. (If needed, beat remaining egg with 1 tablespoon water.)
4. Preheat oven to 200 degrees. Line a baking sheet with paper towels. In a large skillet over medium-high heat, melt 2 tablespoons butter in 4 tablespoons oil. When butter stops bubbling, fry the first batch of cakes until golden brown and crispy, about two minutes per side. Place on baking sheet and put in the oven. Drain off oil and wipe out pan with paper towels. Fry the rest of the cakes in remaining oil and butter.
5. To serve: Place two cakes on each plate. Sprinkle with Parmesan and spoon tomato sauce around them. Garnish with marjoram.
Yield: 7 servings (15 cakes).

GRAPHIC: Photo: Buranee banjan, with eggplant, tomatoes and yogurt, is one of Kabul's best surprises. (Photograph by Peter Lippmann; food and prop stylist: Valerie Lhomme. plate: christiane perrochon, italy.)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property; 
Reckson Is Narrowing Its Focus to Office Buildings

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
THE RECKSON ASSOCIATES REALTY CORPORATION, a real estate investment trust traded on the New York Stock Exchange, grew out of a family company that prospered developing industrial and office properties on Long Island. Since going public in 1995, Reckson has acquired companies, buildings and land in the entire tristate area and has grown to a company whose publicly traded securities are worth more than $3 billion.
 Now, most members of the Rechler family have cut their ties to Reckson and returned to Long Island as owners and managers of a portfolio of 95 industrial properties containing 5.9 million square feet of space. Scott Rechler, who has emerged as the sole chief executive of Reckson, said the separation from the family was part of a package of measures intended to improve the corporate governance of the company and to prepare for continued growth as an owner of office buildings in the metropolitan area. 
 In addition, he said, the industrial properties are not well understood by the investment community. The price of Reckson shares has risen to $24 from about $18 in the last nine months, but whether the decision to divest the industrial property is responsible is debatable since other New York REIT's have also been rising. 
"This was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to transform the company," said Mr. Rechler, who added that the proceeds of the sale of the industrial properties would be reinvested in office buildings with greater prospects for income growth. "We want to trade out of assets with slow or negative growth and into those with positive growth. We are becoming an office company."
Under the terms of the deal, which closed in November, Donald Rechler and his son Mitchell and Roger Rechler and his son Gregg have formed Rechler Equity Partners and have paid $315 million for the industrial portfolio that was begun by Roger and Donald's late father, William Rechler, in 1961.
Donald Rechler, formerly co-chief executive of Reckson and Scott's uncle, will remain with the company as chairman but will have no executive responsibilities. Another Rechler, Todd, who is Scott's younger brother, will remain with Reckson as manager of its New Jersey operations.
When the company first went public, Scott Rechler said, it combined the characteristics of a family company and a publicly owned one, as have many REIT's that emerged from privately owned real estate development companies. But as Reckson grew, the family presence in top management prevented the advance of talented outsiders. And the family's interests and that of outside shareholders have diverged as well, Scott Rechler said.
For example, the sale of a property that made sense for the corporation could trigger unwanted tax bills for family members who owned it before the establishment of the public company.
WITH the changes, only two Rechlers, Donald and Scott, remain on the board, which is now dominated by six outsiders. In addition, antitakeover provisions such as staggered terms for directors have been eliminated to emphasize the rights of shareholders.
The company has also opted out of a New York State law intended to prevent takeovers. Antitakeover provisions are generally viewed as measures intended to protect management over the interests of shareholders, who could get a higher price for their stock if an acquirer successfully bid for the company.
In addition, only Scott Rechler remains in the top management ranks of the company. Previously, Roger Rechler was executive vice president for development, Mitchell Rechler was the chief administrative officer and Gregg Rechler was the chief operating officer of the company.
"In the past, we could balance the family and a public company, but you cannot do both today," Scott Rechler said. "We have to play to the highest standards of corporate governance."
Splitting off the Long Island industrial portfolio had both tactical and strategic advantages, Scott Rechler said. Strategically, income from industrial property on Long Island is likely to increase more slowly than income from the office buildings in Manhattan and central business districts in the suburbs. Tactically, it was a self-contained unit with its own network of business contacts and operations.
Setting the price for a sale from a public company to members of the founding family can be tricky, Scott Rechler said. He said the process was managed by an outside director, Peter Quick, who is president of the American Stock Exchange, based on reports fromassessors. Nevertheless, lawsuits have been filed by some investors protesting the transaction.
THE funds from the sale have been re-deployed into Reckson's latest acquisition, the 42-story, million-square-foot building at 1185 Avenue of the Americas, between 46th and 47th Streets, which was bought for $321 million.
The exchange is paying off from the beginning, Scott Rechler said. The expected income next year from the Long Island properties is $21.8 million, while the income from the Manhattan building is $23 million.
But while the rents for the Long Island buildings are estimated to be 15 percent above the current market, the rents at 1185 Avenue of the Americas are 58 percent below the current market.
Since 40 percent of the leases are expiring over the next eight years, it is expected that the net operating income of the building could be increased by 45 percent by 2011, Mr. Rechler said. That would bring the income from the building to $35.2 million by that time.
Meanwhile, since 60 percent of the leases do not expire until after 2011, the property is stable financially, he said.
Managing skyscraper office towers in Manhattan and other business districts is more lucrative and less administratively messy than groups of smaller buildings in the suburbs, he said. The managers of the Long Island industrial properties have to deal with more than 200 tenants. At 1185 Avenue of the Americas, just seven tenants account for 71 percent of the space. In addition, he indicated that the credit standings were generally higher for the tenants in the Manhattan building than for those in Long Island. 
The sale of the Long Island properties and the purchase of 1185 Avenue of the Americas have greatly increased the importance of the Manhattan market, which Reckson entered when it bought the Tower Realty Trust's 2.3-million-square-foot portfolio in 1998, to the company's income.
Before the sale, Long Island was the largest contributor to earnings with 32 percent, compared with 31 percent for Manhattan and lesser amounts for the Westchester-Connecticut portfolio and New Jersey. The sale shrunk the Long Island contribution to 24 percent while increasing the Manhattan share to 37 percent. The investment in 1185 Avenue of the Americas has further raised the relative contribution of Manhattan to 42 percent.
Owning office skyscrapers in New York City is the equivalent of having whole portfolios of smaller buildings in the suburbs, Mr. Rechler said. One of the company's Manhattan properties is the 1.4-million-square-foot building at 919 Third Avenue at 55th Street. "The income from 919 is greater than that of the entire company when we went public," Mr. Rechler said.
Mr. Rechler said the company would continue to invest in existing buildings in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut as opportunities arose and would hold on to several hundred acres of land until the economic climate was suitable for development, which he estimated would not be until 2006.
"We know how to create value in office buildings," Mr. Rechler said. "We did not lose any of that capability in the sale."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Scott Rechler near Robert Indiana's LOVE sculpture outside Reckson's offices on Avenue of the Americas. (Photo by Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)
