HEADLINE: Asbury Park's Long Recovery 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK 

 BODY:
GABRIELLE SALEMI recently stopped by to check on the granite countertops and ash wood flooring being installed in her new home, one of 30 apartments in the Britwoods Court Apartments, a restored 1920's Spanish Colonial Revival-style building that harkens back to one of this resort town's more luminous periods.
 "I see it as a good investment for the future," said Ms. Salemi, who hopes this city by the sea is on the verge of another rebirth. "I don't have a 401(k) at my business, so I'm putting my money in real estate. I have the vision to wait if I have to." 
 Yet a few blocks away, Jeanine Cinseruli was bemoaning the visionary decision she made five years ago, when she bought a four-family house on Third Street, thinking she would cash in on the wave of mostly gay, urban trendsetters who were just discovering the diamond-in-the-rough appeal of this faded resort. 
 "Some days I think it's really happening, other times I think it's the biggest scam going," said Ms. Cinseruli. "These people who are buying houses here don't really live here. They're coming for weekends. I live with the people, I have tenants. I can't even walk my dog without 18 people asking me if I want to buy coke."
 Comments like these can be heard at the Kingsley Deli, in City Hall, or on almost any street corner in Asbury Park, where the buzz is nearly deafening with people obsessively speculating about the future of a city left devoid of a middle class and ravaged by racial upheaval and municipal corruption. 
 These days, those seemingly certain of a pot of gold at the end of a protracted rainbow point to real estate prices that have increased 25 percent annually for the last few years, the opening of six new restaurants and a string of antique shops along Cookman Avenue downtown, and a $1.2 billion waterfront redevelopment plan that promises thousands of new homes and close to a half-million square feet of new commercial space.
 Yet unconvinced residents and wary real estate investors point with equal vigor to the many for sale signs around town, an indication, they say, of investors cashing out before it is too late, a continuing stream of muggings and gang skirmishes that do not appear to be lessening, and a redevelopment plan that has yet to break ground in a city where sundown is the enemy. 
 In June 2002, Governor McGreevey joined local officials and developers here to praise the latest plan to redevelop the two oceanfront blocks of Asbury Park's mile of shoreline. A year earlier, Oceanfront Acquisitions had purchased the redevelopment rights on 130 acres of land -- 56 of which can be built on -- from the previous developer, Joseph Carabetta, who went bankrupt in 1992. 
 The designated tract falls within the city's larger 230-acre redevelopment zone and includes many of Asbury Park's historic entertainment buildings, residential properties and open land. Master developer Asbury Partners L.L.C. -- a partnership of Oceanfront Acquisitions and D. Sass Municipal Finance Partners -- plans to sell rights to such subdevelopers as Kushner Companies and Paramount Homes, who in turn plan to build 3,000 new apartments and townhouse condominiums as well as 450,000 square feet of retail and entertainment space. 
 At the time of the announcement, the chief operating officer of Asbury Partners, Larry Fishman, said the city would see the first 800 units built within the next six months.
 Almost 18 months later, the only visible signs of progress at the waterfront are some spruced up concession stands and a half-mile stretch of boardwalk now being restored. Before the major construction can begin, the developers need approval from the state Department of Environmental Protection, required under the state's Coastal Area Review Act, in addition to final approval from the city's Planning Board, both of which Mr. Fishman says he expect by this spring.
 Hanging in the balance is a city at once awaiting a boom yet fearful that the runup of real estate prices will flatten, leaving investors with wildly inflated mortgages.
 "This town is very shaky right now," said Rita Morano, the owner of Kingsley Deli, which sits across Kingsley Avenue from the rusted remains of the last attempt at revitalization here. "When you have redevelopment going on, you're supposed to see something happening."
 Countering criticism, Mr. Fishman cited the $8 million boardwalk restoration, selection of subdevelopers, and technical reviews of two pavilions to be restored as "a tremendous amount of progress in a relatively short amount of time." 
 He also acknowledged that some of the studies and surveys required by the state "were much more detailed than we anticipated," noting that the company has invested $30 million on the project to date. 
One issue holding up progress has been a debate over what to do with some of Asbury Park's historic landmarks, like Convention Hall, the Paramount Theater, the Casino, the Carousel House and the Palace, which define the city's past as one of the East Coast's leading resort destinations. Asbury Partners purchased Convention Hall and the Paramount from the city for $5 million, half of which was paid for with a credit the city owed the developers for the boardwalk repairs. Mr. Fishman said the plan is to restore the Carousel house while replacing the Casino and Palace with reasonable facsimiles, a proposal that has upset many preservationists.
 Werner Baumgartner, the city's historian, is equally disturbed by what he sees as the privatization of the city's oceanfront, which the founder of Asbury Park, James Bradley, specifically designated to be used as public space when the city was developed at the turn of the last century.
 "They're ignoring the whole draw of Asbury Park - a resort, oceanfront town - and missing out on the whole heritage tourism economy," said Mr. Baumgartner. "Instead, they're putting up high-density residential and a shopping mall. This is suburban mentality in a Jersey shore resort."
 Moreover, opponents contend that Asbury Partners has spent more time trying to acquire additional property rather than proceeding with development on the land they now own. Any property within the designated area is subject to eminent domain, where the developers have the right to purchase the property for fair market value and raze it to make way for the planned development. While much of the zone consists of empty rubble-strewn lots and boarded up rooming houses, it also includes some private residences and buildings in which other developers have an interest.
 For the last 45 years, Roxy Gokberk has lived in her turn-of-the-century home two blocks from the ocean, in the redevelopment district. She and her son, who lives next door, have been told they can sell their properties now to the developer or wait to be bought out through eminent domain. Stuck in this limbo, Ms. Gokberk said she was reluctant to make costly repairs to her seven-bedroom house even though she has no interest in selling.
 "I've been looking forward to redevelopment, not thinking it would mean I had to move," said the 75-year-old woman. "I'm not anxious to make money off these developers. And I resent the fact that they think it's nothing and that I ought to sell and retire to Florida. This is my American dream." 
 At the Britwoods Court Apartments on Second Avenue, where one developer, Richard DiPetro, was granted the right to restore one of this city's first apartment houses, tenants are now moving into condominiums that sell for $119,000 to $300,000. Like so many of Asbury Park's other grand dames, the Britwoods and its neighbor, the Jersey Court Apartments, had been boarded up for several years. 
 Mr. DiPetro, who has undertaken the rehabilitation of historic buildings in Newark and Jersey City, was brought in eight years ago to assess the two buildings, which he ended up buying last year. While the Britwoods Court was spared the redeveloper's wrecking ball, Mr. DiPetro is in a legal battle with the city and the developers over restoring the Jersey Court. 
 "You can't develop your own property," said Mr. DiPietro. "You have to let the town take it under eminent domain and then buy it back from them."
 Noting that developers have offered to sell him development rights for Jersey Court for $4 million, plus $3 million in infrastructure costs and six percent of gross sales, he said "These guys are being greedy."
 The redevelopment plan calls for subdevelopers to build a full block at a time to ensure that design standards are met and related infrastructure repairs and parking are addressed, according to Mr. Fishman, who said that before the redevelopment plan was drawn up, individual developers showed little interest in Asbury Park.
 "Prior to Asbury Partners coming to Asbury Park, developers such as DiPetro had 20 years to build and did nothing," said Mr. Fishman. "They're looking to piggy back on the development plan that we've committed to." 
 While some residents question the good-faith intent of the developers, others wonder how this crime-plagued city, where 30 percent of its 17,000 residents live below the poverty level, will attract people willing to pay $300,000 for a condominium or invest in the commercial space of the proposed waterfront development.
 In September, the city council was asked to approve a $75,000 emergency appropriation for a "gang violence suppression" program, in the aftermath of a daytime shooting of two Haitians sitting in a parked car on Sewell Avenue. With 40 shootings attributed to gang warfare last year, the police director, Louis Jordan, told the council that "the issue of street gangs is out of control."
 The state's Uniform Crime Report showed violent and nonviolent crime had dropped by about 12 percent in Asbury Park in one year. From 2001 to 2002, the number of murders dropped to 3 from 5, rapes were down to 9 from 14, and robberies fell to 172 from 184. 
 But Al Compoly, a long-time member of Asbury Park's neighborhood watch, suggested that to present a better face to potential investors, the police were underreporting crimes in the city, particularly the drug traffic, which he said was ravaging the city.
 "They want this whole redevelopment thing to go and they want to tell people that crime is down," said Mr. Compoly. "I think that is the wrong message to put across. I certainly wouldn't walk the streets at night."
 Ms. Gokberk agreed, saying she was nervous going out simply to get her newspaper because of the numerous drug transactions she said she witnesses across the street from her house. 
 "I do believe it's getting worse again," she said. "It's more visible. I love to sit on my front porch, but it's all I see."
 Those who are buying into the future of Asbury Park say they are aware of the city's problems. And in fact some say they even welcome what they sense as an urban edginess that is far different from the sanitized shore towns that surround Asbury Park.
 "What interests me most about the place is the diversity," said Damien Miano, a New York City hair salon owner who bought a 1930's townhouse here in September. "I'm not the sort of gay who wants to be in the Hamptons with a bunch of other rich white guys."
 As for the potential dangers, Mr. Miano said, "I'd use the same sense that I would use if I were walking around Manhattan -- somewhere that isn't always so safe."
 Mike Nash recently paid about $600,000 for 4,600-square-foot Victorian three blocks from the ocean and around the corner from a Haitian church and soup kitchen. It is purchases like his that are used as a benchmark when many people speculate whether the market has topped out, or if housing prices have outstripped their real value. But for Mr. Nash, who counsels financially troubled companies and can recognize signs of potential trouble, he insisted that the move to Asbury Park was a good investment.
 "My wife and I decided we were ready to reinvent ourselves, take another look at life," Mr. Nash said. "There are risks, however with the chance of things turning around here, and starting so low, it's not such a big risk."
 Being a businessman, Mr. Nash has been careful to include an escape clause for himself.
 "I've learned over the years that these decisions aren't permanent," he said. "If we go in there, and it's not going where we predicted it would go, we can get out without losing too much and do something else."

HEADLINE: Faith of Our Fitness Centers 

BYLINE:  By TAMMY LA GORCE

 BODY:
THEY are reluctant to acknowledge it, but the religion-based Jewish Community Centers and Y.M.C.A.'s are engaged in a battle for the fitness dollar in New Jersey.
 These two organizations have long been the dominant players in a billion-dollar industry that capitalizes on sweat and muscle, and they continue to evolve even as smaller gyms and workout programs seem to be popping up at every other intersection. 
 Jewish Community Centers used to be known as the Young Men's Hebrew Association until around 20 years ago. "The old name eliminated women and older people," said Alan Mann, an executive vice president at the J.C.C. Association of North America in New York, "and not many people identify themselves as Hebrew anymore."
 Nowadays, the well-toned, the flabby and all body types in between seem to be lining up -- regardless of faith -- at 16 impressively appointed J.C.C. facilities around the state, which is second in concentration only to New York. 
 Like the Y's, the J.C.C.'s are more than pools, saunas, racquetball courts and neat rows of nautilus machines arranged in mirrored, air-conditioned fitness rooms. Though Y's are more ingrained in the national consciousness, J.C.C.'s function in the same community catch-all capacity: For families with young children, they offer preschools, summer camps and after-school care. For retirees, there are socials, classes and lectures. School-age children can join swim leagues or soccer or basketball teams; teens can sequester themselves in their own on-site hangout centers; and singles, in some locations, are matched at mixers and through in-house dating services. Guest speakers -- authors, politicians and other luminaries -- are booked regularly for sessions open to all members.
 Both organizations also share longevity: the country's first Y.M.C.A. was established in Boston in 1851. and the first Y.M.H.A. came a year earlier in Baltimore.
 But unlike the Y's, the J.C.C.'s adhere to an image-consciousness consistent with the times.
 Think Kmart versus Saks. J.C.C.'s operate like a high-profile brand, upholding carefully laid-out standards to meet the demands of a marketplace teeming with increasingly discriminating fitness buffs.
 Recent visits to several locations showed that where a Y employee might scan a member's card wordlessly, for example, front-desk clerks at the Jewish centers make a practice of acknowledging members by name. Where Y's hang vinyl shower curtains in their locker rooms without concern for whether they reach from one stall wall to the other, cloth curtains hang securely, with ample drape, at the J.C.C.'s.
 And then there is the pool smell: At Y's, its fetid dampness is famously pervasive. At J.C.C.'s, air-filtration systems eliminate it and also clear the air of the sweaty-sock odor that clings to most anyplace that regularly plays host to hordes of preschoolers tumbling on mats.
 Despite their differences and head-to-head competition, both groups claim mutual respect and harmonious relationships within communities in which they both operate. 
 "It may be naive of me not to, but we don't consider J.C.C.'s competitors," said Melanie Roth, who trains volunteers and employees and advises on marketing at 27 of the state's 41 Y's as an employee of the YMCA-USA, based in Chicago. 
 J.C.C. spokesmen echo that thought. "Although our goals, services and programs are similar to the Y's, we do not view them competitively because the communities we target are primarily different," said Avi Lewinson, the executive director of the Palisades J.C.C.
 But whether in metropolitan Jewish hubs like eastern Bergen County, Cherry Hill and West Orange or in less Jewish regions like Scotch Plains and Edison, the J.C.C.'s are obviously eclipsing the Y's in customers and customer devotion.
 Jenifer Wirtshafter, a member of the Central New Jersey J.C.C. in Scotch Plains, contends that "Coldwell Banker didn't sell me my house" in Westfield, "the full-service J.C.C. nearby did." 
 The J.C.C. in Cherry Hill has 11,000 members, while the Camden County Y, which includes two branches, one in nearby Voorhees and the other in Camden, has a combined membership of 3,800.
 J.C.C. Metrowest, which includes centers in West Orange and Whippany, has a combined 16,000 members, far above that of the nearest Y's: the West Essex Y in Livingston, near West Orange, which serves 4,800, and the recently refurbished Morris Center Y.M.C.A. in Cedar Knolls, with 5,700 members. 
 And the J.C.C. in Bridgewater has 5,000 members, while the Bridgewater Y, encompassing separate buildings in Bridgewater, Somerville and Hillsborough, has a total of 4,600.
 In a reversal, the Y.M.C.A./Y.W.C.A. in Ridgewood, which serves most of Bergen, Passaic and Rockland counties, has 14,000 members, surpassing the 11,000 members of the J.C.C. on the Palisades, in Tenafly. The annual rate for a family membership at the Y, however, is $540, while the J.C.C. on the Palisades is $300 steeper.
 A tour of the Tenafly grounds illustrates why.
 Reaching the J.C.C. is like arriving at a major destination. A long, winding driveway leads up a hill, past a marquee announcing coming events and to the center of the 34-acre property, a 175,000-square-foot building surrounded by gardens and the kind of statues typically found outside a small-city art museum. 
 An off-duty police officer monitors the front door, which constantly buzzes open and shut for young mothers in spandex, elderly members in windbreakers and briefcase-toting business people, freshly showered post-workout.
 Those who aren't headed toward the sprawling parking lot make their way toward a restaurant where kosher bagels and coffee keep the morning crowd lingering or -- if they're not attending a class, playing squash or racquetball, swimming or shopping at the gift boutique -- to one of two gyms.
 Membership here costs $840 for a family and $380 for a single adult. But 550 of the members have chosen to pay an additional $790 to join this location's Seiden Health Center, the fitness equivalent of a restaurant's V.I.P. room. As these well-heeled members hoist free weights or huff on stationary bikes, an employee in track pants and a crisp polo shirt circles the floor, passing out cups of water to the perspiring and panting as if they were hors d'oeuvres. When their workout is over, these members can elect to hit their own private sauna or whirlpool, pick at a complimentary brunch or choose an aromatherapy treatment in the members-only steam room.
 Downstairs, few of the 10,450 members who choose to work out at the regular gym would consider themselves second-class citizens. Here there are elliptical machines to spare, even during the busy hours of the gym, and a wall of television sets help amply spaced treadmill runners maintain their strides. 
 "I'll go downstairs sometimes and work out too," Vivian Kestenbaum of Englewood, a Seiden member, said recently after racing a friend around the indoor track. "I spend a lot of time here, and it's a nice change of scenery." In addition, she sees people she know from the center's preschool there and "It's a good place for me to book playdates," she said.
 Mr. Mann, the national executive, and Mr. Lewinson, the executive director of the Palisades J.C.C., concede that the Tenafly location is probably the state's most well-appointed. But they don't apologize for its posh or doubt its affordability. 
 The Y's and the J.C.C.'s are part of state, national and international networks, but in both organizations each location sets its own membership dues. Representatives of both organizations say that their fees, as well as their amenities, are reflective of their communities -- the more affluent the region, the pricier and more deluxe the facility. But the J.C.C. of Central New Jersey, which serves Scotch Plains, Westfield, Clark, Fanwood and Berkeley Heights, and the Fanwood-Scotch Plains Y, which is almost directly across the street in Scotch Plains, put that premise to the test.
 In a fairly middle-class area, they would be expected to have similar amenities and similar fees. But at the 26,000-square-foot J.C.C., which was remodeled in 1998 to enhance the fitness studios, teen center and pool, the dues are $665 a year for a family. At the Y, which is almost the same size and was remodeled a decade ago to include a new gym and new adult locker rooms but lacks small perquisites like towel service and blow-dryers, the same membershippackage costs $747.
 J.C.C.'s substantially outperform Y's at fund-raising, which enables them to fit the profile of gyms that Chris Ochart, general manager of the Gold's Gym in Whippany, says attracts fitness connoisseurs. 
 "People come here shopping for a gym a lot," he said, "and usually the deciding factor is price, but mostly they think of Y's as a place for the family, for kids who want to play basketball. And Y's are about the pool, too." The benefit of a private gym like Gold's or the Whippany J.C.C., he said, is the variety and the quantity of machines. "We have volume, and with volume comes convenience," he said. "You don't have to wait all the time." 
 J.C.C. fitness coordinators budget for equipment upgrades and latest-craze classes like Pilates at least annually, and when laying out their plans "some of it is pure consumerism," said Les Cohen, executive director of the Cherry Hill J.C.C. "If we want to stay competitive with private health clubs -- and we do -- we have to make sure we have plenty of treadmills and ellipticals," he said.
 For the remodeling of the J.C.C. in Scotch Plains five years ago, the Central New Jersey Jewish Federation contributed $6 million, said Lois Altschul, assistant executive director. By contrast, Karin Driexler, executive director of the Fanwood-Scotch Plains Y, said her project required a $2.4 million grant from an economic development council and a capital campaign that raised $1 million.
 At the Morris Center Y.M.C.A. at Cedar Knolls, $4 million raised through individual and corporate donors was used primarily to acquire a neighboring building and to place an expanded child-care center in it, enlarging the overall facility to 57,000 square feet, from 37,000.
 The 12,000-member Madison Y raised $5 million through fund-raisers and grants for a 2001 project that enlarged the fitness and family center to 14,000 square feet, from 9,000, while the West Orange branch of the J.C.C. Metrowest raised $14 million through the Central New Jersey Jewish Federation for an overhaul that started only recently.
 The renovation project at the Morris Center Y happened because "everything was outdated," said Michelle Breslin, its public relations coordinator. "I don't think we were losing memberships," she said, "but our base wasn't as strong."
 The fund-raising difference between Y's and J.C.C.'s may be demographic as well as cultural.
 "Historically, the Jewish community in New Jersey has very strong philanthropic support," said Eric Robbins, associate executive director of the Metrowest J.C.C. 
 Metrowest, which moved to West Orange 40 years ago and built a branch center in Whippany eight years ago, has roots in Newark, he added. 
 "And Newark has one of the strongest Jewish communities in the state," Mr. Robbins said. "That's continued in the culture. Probably, per capita, we raise a lot more money than other facilities. But that's in our history and our community's culture of giving."
 However the money gets there, members like Elvy Saraceno and Gina Berez, both of West Orange, appreciate the way it is being spent.
 "I come three or four times a week for kickboxing, dancing -- to work out," Ms. Saraceno said while walking briskly on a treadmill at the West Orange J.C.C., part of a routine she has established in the two years since she joined. "Everybody knows everybody, and you can always find something you want to do."
 Ms. Berez, a three-year member, said she preferred the West Orange site to other gyms like New York Sports. "There's not a show-off environment," she said. "No one's looking at you here."
 Neither Ms. Saraceno or Ms. Berez is Jewish. Exact breakdowns of religious affiliations were not available, but the directors of several J.C.C.'s said their memberships were about 20 percent non-Jewish. Some sites used to be exclusively Jewish, but non-Jewish memberships have picked up steadily through the years. The crowd of people working out at the J.C.C. in Whippany, for example, is typically a mix of cultures, including many Asians and a sprinkling of blacks.
 "There's no doubt that J.C.C.'s have changed," said Michael Hopkins, executive director of J.C.C. Metrowest, who has worked at various centers in various capacities since 1979, "and that the trend now is in serving the entire community." 
 Still, the keep-to-yourself environment that Ms. Berez appreciates in the fitness center doesn't necessarily extend to religious expression.
 For all the talk of inclusiveness -- "We'll take a member regardless of why," said Mr. Mann of the national association -- J.C.C.'s don't shrink from their mission to promote Jewish culture. 
 Their purpose is "to further the Jewish journey," as Mr. Mann put it. To that end, the Web sites of several J.C.C.'s note that non-Jewish food is not allowed on the premises.
 By comparison, the Y's Christian-based guiding philosophy -- the motto "We build strong kids, strong families, strong communities" is its answer to the J.C.C.'s "Shalom, you're right where you belong" -- may feel muted to its members. Its Christian principles are most visible in its community service commitments.
 As Ms. Roth of the YMCA-USA points out, most Y's efforts to impress their members in the gym come second to the more altruistic goal of sifting out needs within their towns. 
 "We'll tailor specific programs," she said. "In Newark and Paterson, the Y's are providing after-school literacy programs; they're doing job placement of teens." They also sometimes provide language classes for people who don't speak English.
 "There are very small Y's having an impact on their communities," she added. "At the Salem County Y.M.C.A. in Carneys Point, they may not have the fastest computers or the best playgrounds, but it's keeping its doors open, and that's making a difference for people there. It's a safe place to go."
 Y's make allowances through scholarships and private programs for people who would like to join but can't afford to. "We'll work with anybody who is interested in becoming a member to help," Ms. Roth said; the message to on-hold callers at the YMCA-USA repeats the reassurance that "no one is turned away because of inability to pay." 
 The principle at J.C.C.'s is similar but less guaranteed. "If you can't afford to be a part of a program but would like to, we have various different ways of helping," said Mr. Lewinson of the Palisades, "but we'll work out what a person can pay, whatever that amount is, because even if it's a dollar, we want to see that the person values the program."
 Both organizations count on the United Way for contributions, in addition to private donors and corporations, and both make a specialty of resourcefulness. When Ms. Roth visited the Westfield Y in 2001 for staff training, for example, employees from the J.C.C. of Central New Jersey sat in. "We're two organizations both working with committees and volunteers, so we figured, why not work together?" she said. 
 More significant, the Y and the J.C.C. in Edison are housed under the same roof on Oak Tree Road.
 "It wasn't a merger," explained Dorothy Rubinstein, executive director of the J.C.C., "but the J.C.C. had alarge debt" -- going back to 1985, when it opened -- "and we were never able to solve it." Several years ago, she said, the chief executive of the Metuchen/Woodbridge Y called to suggest a joint program.
 "We were overcrowded in Metuchen," explained Cindi Archambault, executive director of the Edison branch of what is now called the Metuchen/Edison/Woodbridge YMCA, "so we purchased some property from the J.C.C., an adjoining building." After hashing out the details over a five-year period, the J.C.C.-Y.M.C.A. combination opened its doors last December. 
 "We remain two separate organizations," Ms. Rubinstein said. "We're sectarian, and the Y.M.C.A. is nonsectarian, but now everybody shares the gym, the pool, the cardio equipment, the multipurpose room, and also community-wide events" in the 23,000-square-foot building. 
 "We're set up to be noncompetitive," she said, and the concept is working. "Before we joined, we had under 1,000 families as members. We've had 6,000 new memberships in the past 10 months. We should be a model for J.C.C.'s and Y.M.C.A.'s everywhere."

HEADLINE: It's Come to This: Couch Potatoes as a Tourist Attraction 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK

 BODY:
Call it silly, but this could be one of the best signs the economy has shown in months.
 Breaking records for the sheer sport of it is traditionally associated with boom times like the Roaring Twenties, when pole-sitters sought to outlast one another in fabricated tests of endurance and will, or the 1990's, when a man named David Blaine had himself buried alive. 
 Seeking to carve their own names into the roster of that bold lineage, a small band of movie enthusiasts huddled together in the "Good Morning America" studio in Times Square this weekend to watch movies for hours on end.
Specifically, these people hope to keep their eyes focused on a 10-by-7 1/2-foot screen for longer than 66 hours and 17 minutes, the record set in Germany in October. 
They passed the 24-hour mark at 10 a.m. yesterday, a group 19 strong after one dropout overnight, and were on a course to eclipse the record by the early morning hours of Monday.
But whether or not they succeed, the true aim of this stunt has already been accomplished. Netflix, an Internet movie rental company and the sponsor and organizer of the record attempt, put its name on banners all over the outside of the studio and posted people in old-fashioned usher uniforms on the street to pass out promotional fliers. A spokeswoman for the company declined to say how much the whole affair cost.
People in Times Square stopped to press their noses against the windows and stare at the movie-watchers in their human fishbowl, fulfilling the consumer end of this common Times Square promotional ploy.
"It looks like an experiment in social Darwinism," said Joe Mathers, 27, one of the barkers dressed in usher attire. The most oft-repeated query from passers-by, Mr. Mathers said, centered on the participants' ability to leave their posts and do their business, so to speak.
The answer, Netflix employees said, was that there was a five-minute break between each movie and a 15-minute break every third movie. "We're not trying to torture them," said Shannon Clouston, 32, a manager of the event who worked in shifts and slept in her own bed at night.
The participants, unpaid volunteers lured by the company because of their prior willingness to engage in so-called focus groups, enjoyed no such luxury. They were arrayed on sofas and padded chairs, sitting upright, their eyes looking toward the screen at the front of the room at all times. Two young women sat facing the participants, watching their eyes to certify the record.
Boxes of food and water bottles were kept within reach. There was a container of skin lotion on one table and a bottle of liquid antacid on another.
Each of the participants had suggested five movies, and the company had provided several dozen digital video discs, which were separated into daytime and nighttime boxes in order to ensure that nothing ribald was played on the big screens as families of tourists peered in during the day.
After starting with "Die Hard," the participants screened "The Jerk," "American Beauty," "Jurassic Park," "The Shining" and "Blazing Saddles," among others. By midday yesterday, they were bouncing dangerously between heights of brow, following "Dr. Strangelove (or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb)" with "Dumb and Dumber."
The group appeared to comprise mostly people in their 20's and 30's, with a couple of middle-aged men mixed in. There was a Tae Kwon Do expert, a computer engineer, an insurance salesman, an actor and a wax-museum manager.
Cheryl Jones, 33, of Long Island, who was interviewed from the side because she was not allowed to avert her gaze from the screen, spoke modestly of her potential to make the kind of history documented in a book named after an Irish brewery.
"This is probably the only opportunity I'm going to have to break a record unless it's an accident, like 'lived after being hit by a 2-by-4,' " she said, revealing perhaps too much of her subconscious life due to her sleep-deprived state. "No special talents."
Nearby, Ekin Binal, 24, of Connecticut, shared a couch with two women and endeavored to keep them focused by means of occasional nudging and a breathtakingly simple game wherein he selected a movie character's name and hollered it every time it was mentioned on screen.
Behind the fake living room created in the studio, an area was set up for Netflix workers to prepare food and store water. The whole thing was protected from the tourists outside by a security guard sitting in a booth, stark and drab compared with the pillow-laden living room set, with a television on -- tuned to a basketball game.

HEADLINE: New Medicare Plan For Drug Benefits Prohibits Insurance 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
Medicare beneficiaries will not be allowed to buy insurance to cover their share of prescription drug costs under the new Medicare bill to be signed on Monday by President Bush, the legislation says.
 Millions of Medicare beneficiaries have bought private insurance to fill gaps in Medicare. But a little-noticed provision of the legislation prohibits the sale of any Medigap policy that would help pay drug costs after Jan. 1, 2006, when the new Medicare drug benefit becomes available. 
 This is one of many surprises awaiting beneficiaries, who will find big gaps in the drug benefit and might want private insurance to plug the holes -- just as they buy insurance to supplement Medicare coverage of doctors' services and hospital care. 
Congress cited two reasons for banning the sale of Medigap drug policies. Lawmakers wanted to prevent duplication of the new Medicare benefit. They also wanted to be sure that beneficiaries would bear some of the cost. Health economists have long asserted that when beneficiaries are insulated from the costs, they tend to overuse medical services.
Gail E. Shearer, a health policy analyst at Consumers Union, said she had mixed feelings about the prohibition.
"I don't want a return to abuses of 1970's and 80's, when lots of confusing Medigap policies were sold to vulnerable seniors," Ms. Shearer said. But she added: "Many seniors and disabled people will face a huge gap in drug coverage. In a bill that's marketed as providing choice to consumers, comprehensive drug coverage is not really an option. That's a disappointment."
The new drug benefit would be the biggest expansion of Medicare since creation of the program in 1965. But patients would still face substantial costs.
Under the standard Medicare drug benefit, the beneficiary would be responsible for a $250 deductible, 25 percent of drug costs from $251 to $2,250 and all of the next $2,850 in drug costs. Private Medigap policies could not cover any of those costs.
A Medicare drug plan could further limit coverage by establishing a list of preferred medicines known as a formulary. The list must include drugs in each "therapeutic category and class" -- antihistamines, antidepressants and cholesterol-lowering agents, for example.
But Medicare would not have to pay anything for drugs left off the list. While patients could appeal a denial of coverage, they could not buy private insurance to cover the costs of such drugs.
Under the standard benefit, a Medicare recipient would pay $3,600 of the first $5,100 of drug costs. After that, Medicare would pay 95 percent of the cost of each prescription. In theory, the bill establishes a limit of $3,600 a year on out-of-pocket costs.
But if a beneficiary bought drugs not listed on the formulary, the bill says, those costs would not be counted toward the $3,600 limit.
Congress began regulating the Medigap market in 1990, as a way to protect consumers, many of whom had bought duplicative policies. The federal government and state insurance commissioners developed 10 standard policies, to replace thousands then on the market.
Three of the 10 Medigap policies cover drugs. Under the legislation, an old policy with drug benefits could be renewed -- but only by a person who chose to forgo the new Medicare drug benefit. A person who enrolls in the new program could not buy or renew a Medigap policy to help defray drug costs.
Nearly 12 million retirees have drug coverage and other health benefits from former employers. If those retirees sign up for the Medicare benefit, the employers can help pay the beneficiaries' share of drug costs. But those payments would not count toward the $3,600 limit on out-of-pocket spending.
Under the bill, low-income elderly people eligible for both Medicare and Medicaid, the federal-state program for low-income people, would receive their drugs through Medicare. Medicare drug plans will almost certainly cover fewer drugs than Medicaid now covers, state officials say. But the bill generally prohibits Medicaid programs from supplementing the Medicare drug benefit.
If state officials wanted to supplement the new Medicare drug benefit, they would have to pick up the entire cost of the extra coverage. States would not get the discounts and rebates they now receive from manufacturers under Medicaid.
Dr. Lynn V. Mitchell, the Medicaid director in Oklahoma, said she expected Medicare formularies to be "more restrictive" than the drug coverage policies of state Medicaid programs.
"If patients do not get optimal drug therapy," Dr. Mitchell said, "costs will balloon in other areas. Patients may need more inpatient hospital care."
House and Senate negotiators who worked on the Medicare bill encouraged the National Association of Insurance Commissioners to study the Medigap market, with a view to making major changes.
In a report accompanying the bill, the conference committee said Medigap policies should be revised to provide less upfront coverage and to require beneficiaries to pay more of the initial costs of hospital and physician services.
"Numerous studies have demonstrated that covering deductibles and coinsurance has led to higher Medicare spending because beneficiaries become insensitive to costs," the report said. "Beneficiaries with Medigap consume $1,400 more in Medicare services than beneficiaries without supplemental coverage."
This, it said, "drives up costs for everyone -- premiums of Medicare beneficiaries without Medigap coverage and costs to taxpayers."

HEADLINE: WORTH NOTING; 
For Insurance Industry, Another Transition

BYLINE:  By AVI SALZMAN

 BODY:
The Hartford Financial Services Group announced last Monday that it had agreed to acquire CNA's group life and accident insurance, short-term and long-term disability and certain specialty businesses. CNA is based in Chicago. 
 The announcement came one week after two deals involving Hartford-based Travelers Property Casualty Corporation and CIGNA were announced. 
 The most recent announcement will likely enable Hartford Financial Services to increase the scale of its operations, but the outlook for jobs in Connecticut is still murky.
The Hartford and CNA planned to cut about 10 percent of the work force once the deal goes through, but company representatives were not sure if any Connecticut workers would be let go.
"They don't know where those reductions will come, which divisions, certainly not which states," said Kristin Flyntz, a spokeswoman for the Hartford.
Ms. Flyntz said a committee would spend 60 to 90 days determining the composition of the new company.
The deal could bring new taxpayers to the state if employees of CNA are relocated. The Hartford currently employs 1,146 people in its group benefits division in Connecticut.
Harry Freeman, executive director of the Hartford Economic Development Commission, which is partially financed by the city, was optimistic. "This is one example of a strong Hartford-based company becoming even stronger," he said. AVI SALZMAN

HEADLINE: WORTH NOTING; 
Yes, We Have a Winner, So Hold the Vote Bridgeport

BYLINE:  By JEFF HOLTZ

 BODY:
What was expected to be a close vote for the presidency of Bridgeport's City Council on Monday night never took place.
 Instead, Councilman Andres Ayala Jr., a Democrat who has held the position since the ascension of John M. Fabrizi, the former council president, to the mayoral seat in April, won by acclamation. 
 The challenger, Councilman Robert P. Curwen Sr., a Democrat, said he decided to support his opponent on Monday afternoon after learning that two previously undecided members of the 20-person council had decided to back Mr. Ayala. 
"Obviously, he did his work and got his votes," said Mr. Curwen, referring to Mr. Ayala. "So I congratulate him on that. I have nothing but admiration for my counterpart. Andre and I are friends. When this process began, I asked him to separate politics from friendship. We've both done that. Now it's time to go to work."
Mr. Ayala said he had hoped an agreement on the presidency would have come sooner, but the presence of eight new members on the council slowed things down.
"Bob and myself sat down this afternoon and decided what would be best for the city," he said. "The best thing for the city is myself as president and Bob as budget co-chair."
Mr. Ayala, a teacher at Bridgeport's Bassick High School, said the biggest issues facing the city are the aftermath of the corruption scandal under the former mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, economic development, taxes and education. Mr. Ayala said he believed working with a mayor who was once a City Council president will make his job easier.
"It creates an opportunity for some dialog," he said. 
"The mayor understands what council work is," he said, "and the frustration of dealing with an executive branch that at some times wasn't very open."
Mr. Fabrizi said he felt good about the way Mr. Ayala was selected.
"It showed unity," he said. "People exemplified leadership. It looks like everyone is concentrated and focused on continuing to move the city forward." JEFF HOLTZ

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Big Spenders on Campus Spending Your Money

BYLINE:  By SELENA ROBERTS

 BODY:
THERE are public schools on the plains closing up as easily as pop-up books, but there is a window in the dusty gloom, and, with a little Windex, the elite can watch Nebraska's own Huskers play from that skybox perched in the heavens.
 There are hardworking taxpayers boarding up storefronts in shrinking towns that are down to their last stoplight, but the Mayor of Husker Nation, Steve Pederson, recently handed nearly $800,000 to the state employee Frank Solich to make him disappear after a 9-3 season. 
 As Timothy Egan reported last week in The New York Times, Nebraska has 7 of the nation's 12 poorest counties, but Pederson, also known as Nebraska's athletic director, will soon lure a replacement coach into his department's deep pockets with a salary in the $1 million range, maybe even more.
"At no point do taxpayers pay for the athletic department," said Nancy Kenny, Nebraska's associate athletic director, when reached last week. "We are 100 percent self-supporting." 
For a moment, ignore how this fiscal isolation has left Nebraska's frothy football lords disconnected from reality, and take Kenny at her good word. As the only game in the state, where a Husker jersey's closest competition might be a John Deere cap, Nebraska athletics may well have a claim on independence.
Other Division I shopoholics, from Ohio State to Florida State, rely on state bonds or student fees or taxes on tickets -- or all of the above -- to finance their $100 million-plus in facility upgrades, each college desperate to create the "wow" factor for a 17-year-old blue-chip recruit, who, no doubt, could be wowed by a double cheeseburger. 
To woo celebrity coaches, public universities offer cars, special housing options and low-interest loans that do not register in the salaries of these state employees. To secure the sideline rock stars, there are lucrative buyouts that are the envy of every faculty member with a worn elbow patch and a broken bicycle spoke.
"It's appalling," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College, who wrote "Unpaid Professionals: Commercialism and Conflict in Big-Time College Sports" (Princeton University Press, 1999). "There are coaches walking away with golden handshakes, something you might think taxpayers would complain about." 
Other Division I big spenders, like Oregon, turn to wealthy alumni, like Nike's Phil Knight, for capital improvements, eager to replace the stench and monotony of a weight room with climate-controlled features and plasma-screen televisions. Can't pay an athlete? Then make their stay a spa experience.
"I think we have engaged in an ungodly arms race," Vanderbilt's chancellor, E. Gordon Gee, said in a telephone interview on Thursday. "I leapt off first."
In September, Gee boldly decided to end the athletic department's separate kingdom, reintegrating it into the institution. The restructuring is intended to end athletic segregation, underscored when universities offer coaches their own salary scale and hand athletes separate cafeterias, workout facilities, dorms, classrooms and, in many cases, educational expectations. 
Easy for Vanderbilt, right? After all, the SAT stat leaders are the first to hand over their milk money as the Southeastern Conference's pushover. As Gee has said, he would "be pumping gas" if he had tried this at one of his previous stops, like Ohio State.
But this is a start, a first step toward perspective. Other officials shout "change" only to reveal their bankrupt integrity. Last week, Auburn officials boarded a booster's plane for a clandestine meeting with Louisville's Bobby Petrino, even though Tommy Tuberville was under contract, even though it would cost $4 million to terminate their football coach. Once the secret meeting was disclosed, Tuberville accepted an apology, but angry alumni have called for the resignation of Auburn's president, William Walker, who was aboard the luxury jet.
Merely another moment in a conga line of recent N.C.A.A. embarrassments. Is that Alabama smirking? As a sign of its selective morality, Alabama quickly distanced itself from Mike Price once officials discovered that his drunken night at a strip club would be detailed in a Sports Illustrated article. Price contends in a lawsuit that the article is grossly inaccurate. 
"Alabama never investigated the Sports Illustrated article," Price's lawyer, Stephen Heninger, said by phone last week from his office in Birmingham, Ala. "The president told the football team he was staying. The next morning, it was over."
Hand back the university car, move out of the luxury condo, return the college credit card. The perks were over for Price. The university's president, Robert E. Witt, had taken a stand, forced as it was.
In an ethical pinch, there is oversight by presidents. Otherwise, there is athletic department autonomy, with A.D.'s operating as corporate chief executives. Son need a job? No problem. Feeling insecure? Golden parachutes for all. 
"There is a crisis of confidence," Gee said. "If we don't solve it, we should abandon the athletic departments and turn them over to pros, and tell them, here is your farm system."
Until then, the N.F.L. and the N.B.A. get the farm free as state athletic departments continue their Caligula ways, looking at reality through the window of a skybox, siphoning states for support, trusting that taxpayers won't catch on.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nebraska Athletic Director Steve Pederson fired Frank Solich last week after a 9-3 season. (Photo by Associated Press)
